THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of R. Ryan 
				Breckenridge, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26515
Submitted June 16, 2008 - Filed July 14, 2008Â  
DEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				Lesley M.
  Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and William C. Campbell, Assistant Disciplinary
  Counsel, both of Columbia, forÂ  Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
				Desa A.
  Ballard, of Law Offices of Desa Ballard, P.A., of West Columbia, for
  respondent.Â  
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered
  into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21,
  RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and
  consents to the imposition of an admonition, public reprimand, or a definite
  suspension not to exceed thirty (30) days.Â  See Rule 7(b), RLDE,
  Rule 413, SCACR.Â  We accept the Agreement and
  definitely suspend respondent from the practice of law in this state for a
  thirty (30) day period.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as
  follows.Â  
FACTS
Respondent
  admits that, as a result of his failure to properly maintain his trust account
  and to safeguard client property, several non-sufficient fund (NSF) reports
  were filed with ODC during a six month period of time.Â  During ODCâ€™s
  investigation of the NSF reports, respondent admits that he failed to insure
  that funds were properly credited to his trust account and, as a consequence, a
  check was issued which resulted in an additional NSF report to ODC.Â  Respondent
  represents the account is presently reconciled and that no clients were
  harmed.Â  ODC does not dispute these assertions.Â Â  
Respondent
  asserts that he is aware of the â€œgood funds rule.â€Â  Further, he is aware of the
  importance of verifying the availability of funds prior to disbursement.Â  
Respondent
  admits that, as a result of his failure to fully supervise his staff, a staff
  member was able to take funds from the firm.Â  Respondent has filed criminal
  charges against the staff member and has replaced the missing funds. 
Finally,
  respondent admits that he failed to insure that a mobile home title was
  properly transferred to his client (the buyer) at closing and that he failed to
  communicate with his client for an extended period of time.Â  Respondent
  represents the title to the mobile home has been transferred to his client.Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Respondent
  has not been previously cautioned or sanctioned for misconduct by the
  Commission on Lawyer Conduct or its predecessor, the Board of Commissioners on
  Grievances and Discipline.Â Â Â  Â Â 
LAW
Respondent
  admits that by his misconduct he has violated the following provisions of the
  Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  
Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide
    competent representation); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence
    and promptness in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall promptly
    comply with reasonable requests for information); Rule 5.3(b) (lawyer having
  direct supervisory authority over non-lawyer employee shall make reasonable
  efforts to ensure that the personâ€™s conduct is compatible with the professional
  obligations of the lawyer); and Rule 1.15
    (lawyer shall safeguard client property). Â In addition, respondent
  admits he violated the recordkeeping provisions of Rule 417, SCACR.Â  Finally, respondent
  admits his misconduct constitutes a violation of Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413,
  SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of
  Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding
  professional conduct of lawyers).Â Â Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement and definitely
  suspend respondent from the practice of law for a thirty (30) day period.Â 
  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an
  affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30,
  RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES,
  BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice John W. Kittredge, concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				MRI at Belfair,
      LLC, Appellant,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Health and Environmental Control and Coastal Carolina Medical    Center, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal from the State of South Carolina
Board of Health and Environmental Control
Opinion No.Â  26517
Heard February 7, 2008 - Filed July 14,
  2008Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				M. Elizabeth Crum, A. Victor Rawl, Jr., and Ariail B. Kirk, all of
  Â McNair Law Firm, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Nancy S. Layman and Ashley C. Biggers, both of S.C. Department of
  Health and Environmental Control, of Columbia; Stuart M. Andrews, Jr., Travis
  Dayhuff, and Jennifer I. Cooke, all of Nelson, Mullins, Riley &
  Scarborough, of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  This appeal arises from
  an application for a certificate of need (â€œCONâ€) for a fixed magnetic resonance
  imaging (â€œMRIâ€) unit to be located at Coastal Carolina Medical Center (â€œCCMCâ€
  or â€œHospitalâ€) in Jasper County.Â  DHEC granted a CON to CCMC, and MRI at
  Belfair (â€œappellantâ€) requested a contested case hearing before the Administrative Law Court (â€œALCâ€).Â  The ALC upheld the decision to grant the CON, and the
  South Carolina Board of Health and Environmental Control (â€œBoardâ€) affirmed the
  ALC order.Â  Appellant appealed the Boardâ€™s order to the Court of Appeals, and we
  certified the appeal pursuant to Rule 204, SCACR.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
In
  2004, CCMC submitted an application for a CON to DHEC pursuant to the 2003
  State Health Plan (â€œPlanâ€).[1]Â 
  CCMC sought to provide MRI services at the Hospitalâ€™s forty-one bed acute care
  facility in Hardeeville.Â  CCMC opened in 2004 and provides medical care,
  including an emergency room, twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week. Â The
  Hospital is located near Interstate 95, and its primary service area encompasses
  Jasper and Beaufort Counties.
Appellant is a
  limited liability company owned and operated by Dr. Joseph Borelli, Jr., and it
  is a free-standing, mobile MRI facility.Â  Appellant provides MRI services in
  Bluffton, which is in Beaufort County, located approximately 13.8 miles from
  CCMC.Â  Dr. Borelli is the sole physician who reads the MRI scans, and appellant
  is open for business from 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday through Friday.Â  
After CCMC filed
  its application and DHEC began its review, appellant opposed the grant of a CON
  to CCMC.Â  DHEC approved CCMCâ€™s CON application to provide MRI services to its
  inpatients, outpatients, and emergency patients.Â  
Thereafter,
  appellant requested a contested case hearing before the ALC, naming DHEC and
  CCMC as respondents.Â  Appellant argued that the purposes of the CON Act would
  be best served by CCMC providing MRI services through a shared arrangement of
  either mobile MRI services, an ownership sharing arrangement, or a transfer
  agreement, none of which had to be with appellant.Â  CCMC contended that because
  it was a hospital, it needed MRI accessibility twenty-four hours a day, seven
  days a week.Â  
Prior
  to the ALC hearing, CCMC and appellant filed motions for summary judgment.Â 
  CCMC argued that because the Plan standards provided that hospitals, whenever
  possible, should have at least one MRI unit available for the diagnosis of
  inpatients, outpatients, and emergency patients, CCMC should be granted the CON
  as a matter of law.Â  Appellantâ€™s motion for summary judgment was based on the
  assertion that Plan standards for MRI services and equipment did not comply
  with Â§ 44-7-180(B) and that the DHEC exceeded its statutory authority by
  relying on the MRI Plan standards.Â  The ALC denied appellantâ€™s motion but granted
  partial summary judgment to CCMC, ruling that the MRI standards under the Plan
  did not require CCMC to establish compliance with project review criteria.[2] Â The case proceeded to trial to determine what constituted â€œavailableâ€ under
  the MRI Plan standard.Â  
After a hearing on
  the merits, the ALC affirmed DHECâ€™s decision to grant the CON.Â  The ALC ruled
  that for MRI services to be sufficiently available to CCMC, the Hospital would
  need a fixed, in-house MRI unit that would be accessible twenty-four hours a
  day, seven days a week.Â  Appellant appealed to the Board, and the Board
  affirmed and incorporated the ALC decision in its order. 
ISSUES

	I.  Do
  the MRI standards found in the Plan violate the CON Act, thereby causing the
  Board to exceed its statutory authority in approving the CON awarded to CCMC?
	II.  Is
  the Boardâ€™s determination that an â€œavailableâ€ MRI for CCMC could only be
  achieved by an onsite MRI facility arbitrary and capricious or otherwise
  affected by an abuse of discretion?
	III.  Is
  the finding that the Plan standards did not require CCMC to establish the
  project review criteria violative of Â§ 44-7-210?

ANALYSIS
This appeal is
  governed by the Adminstrative Procedures Act (â€œAPAâ€), S.C. Code Ann Â§Â§
  1-23-310, et seq. (Supp. 2005).Â  We may reverse or modify the Boardâ€™s
  order if appellantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the
  administrative decisions are: a) in violation of constitutional or statutory
  provisions; b) in excess of the statutory authority of the agency; c) made upon
  unlawful procedure; d) affected by other error of law; e) clearly erroneous in
  view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record;
  or f) arbitrary or capricious or characterized by abuse of discretion or
  clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(5).Â  As
  to factual issues, judicial review of administrative agency orders is limited
  to a determination whether the order is supported by substantial evidence.Â  Roper
    Hosp. v. Bd. of S.C. DHEC, 306 S.C. 138, 140, 410 S.E.2d 558, 559 (1991).

I.  State Health Plan 
Appellant
  challenges the validity of the standards for MRI services set forth in the
  Plan.Â  First, appellant argues that the CON award violates Â§ 44-7-180(B)(2) and
  (3) because the Planâ€™s standards for MRI services do not contain projections of
  need or standards of distribution.Â  We disagree.[3]
Section 44-7-180(B)(2)
  and (3) of the CON Act requires the State Health Plan, at a minimum, to
  include:

	(2)
  projections of need for additional health care facilities, beds, health
  services, and equipment;
	(3)
  standards for distribution of health care facilities, beds, specified health
  services, and equipment including scope of services to be provided,
  utilization, and occupancy rates, travel time, regionalization, other factors
  relating to proper placement of services, and proper planning of health care
  facilities; 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  44-7-180(B).Â  
The 2003 State
  Health Plan sets forth three standards for MRI distribution:

	1)  Each
  hospital should have at least one MRI unit available for diagnosis of emergency
  patients, inpatients and outpatients.
	2)  In
  order to promote cost-effectiveness, the use of shared mobile MRI units should
  be considered.
	3)  The
  applicant agrees in writing to provide the Department utilization data on the
  operation of the MRI service.

Although the Plan
  does not give specific projections of need or standards of distribution in
  terms that track the exact statutory language, the Plan does not violate Â§
  44-7-180.Â  Clearly, the first MRI standard that each hospital should
  have at least one MRI unit available satisfies the statuteâ€™s directive for
  projections of need when a hospital applies for a CON of an MRI.Â  The second
  MRI standard also provides guidance for distribution and utilization of
  existing MRI resources.Â  The Plan satisfies the requirements of Â§ 44-7-180(B)(2)
  and (3) by unmistakably stating the need and guiding distribution for MRI units
  in hospitals.Â  See Bursey v. S.C. DHEC, 369 S.C. 176, 631 S.E.2d
  899(2006) (cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and
  effectuate legislative intent).Â  Accordingly, the Plan is not violative of the
  CON Act, and the Board did not exceed its statutory authority in granting the
  CON in light of the Plan standards.[4]
Appellant also
  argues that the Boardâ€™s order should be reversed because there is no statutory
  basis to treat hospitals differently from other health care facilities.Â  We
  disagree.
Even though there
  is no specific provision in the CON Act that authorizes hospitals to be treated
  differently vis-Ã -vis standards of need for MRI services, the ability of the
  Plan to differentiate between different types of medical providers is essential
  to the CON process.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-150 (department may adopt
  substantive and procedural regulations considered necessary by the department
  and approved by the board to carry out the departmentâ€™s licensure and CON
  duties).Â  Furthermore, appellantâ€™s contention that first Plan standard results
  in hospitals being treated differently from other health care facilities is
  misguided.Â  The first Plan standard only satisfies the showing of need for
  hospitals, while other health care facilities will have to document need
  separately.Â  Nothing in the CON Act prevents such a distinction.Â  See S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-130 (containing separate definitions for â€œhospitalâ€ and
  â€œhealth care facilityâ€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-150.
II.  Determination of
  â€œAvailableâ€
The issue addressed
  at trial was whether CCMC had access to an â€œavailableâ€ mobile MRI facility so
  that a CON for an onsite MRI would not be warranted under the Plan standards.Â 
  Appellant argues that the finding of the Board that â€œavailable,â€ in the context
  of MRI service for a hospital, meant an onsite MRI unit was arbitrary,
  capricious, and clearly erroneous.Â  We disagree.
CCMC presented
  testimony from Dr. Tricia Etheridge, CCMCâ€™s chief of staff, concerning the
  difficulties of transporting patients to an off-site MRI or other diagnostic
  facilities.Â  In addition, Dr. Etheridge testified as to her concerns over the
  adequacy of the technology found in mobile MRI units. Â Dr. Dean Mesh, a
  radiologist at CCMC, also testified as to the necessity for an onsite MRI facility
  to handle patients from the Hospitalâ€™s emergency room.Â  The president and CEO
  of CCMC, Eric Deaton, also testified at length concerning the needs for around-the-clock
  MRI availability, especially in light of CCMCâ€™s proximity to I-95.Â  Finally,
  CCMC presented an expert witness, Mark Richardson, who testified that a MRI
  facility open twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week, was in the best
  interests of CCMCâ€™s patients.Â  Accordingly, substantial evidence exists to
  support the finding that an â€œavailableâ€ MRI facility for CCMCâ€™s needs would
  require an onsite MRI facility that was accessible twenty-four hours a day,
  seven days a week.
III.  Project Review
  Criteria
Appellantâ€™s
  final argument claiming that the Board exceeded its statutory authority in granting
  the CON involves S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-210.Â  Appellant argues the Boardâ€™s
  finding that the Plan standards did not require CCMC to establish the project
  review criteria[5] is violative of Â§ 44-7-210.Â  We agree.

	Section 44-7-210(C)
  provides, in relevant part:
	The
  department may not issue a Certificate of Need [CON] unless an application
  complies with the State Health Plan, Project Review Criteria, and other
  regulations.Â  Based on project review criteria and other regulations, which
  must be identified by the department, the department may refuse to issue a
  Certificate of Need even if an application complies with the State Health Plan.

See
  also 24A S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 61-15 Â§
  307.1 (Supp. 2005) (department may refuse to issue a CON even if an application
  is in compliance with the State Health Plan but is inconsistent with project
  review criteria or departmental regulations).
The Board
  determined that the first Plan standard for MRI services stating every hospital
  should have an available MRI unit meant that CCMC did not have to establish the
  project review criteria.Â  This was error.Â  Section 44-7-210(C) and the
  governing regulations are clear in establishing Plan standards and project
  review criteria as separate and distinct requirements that must be met as part
  of the CON application process.Â  Because the Board held that CCMC did not have
  to prove compliance with the project review criteria by virtue of the first
  Plan standard, appellant was prohibited from presenting its case to challenge
  CCMCâ€™s compliance with the project review criteria.Â  Again, CCMCâ€™s compliance
  with the project review criteria is an essential step in the CON process, and
  this prerequisite is independent of compliance with the State Health Plan.Â 
  Accordingly, we remand this case to the ALC to determine whether CCMCâ€™s
  application for a fixed, in-house MRI unit satisfies the project review
  criteria identified in the Plan.
CONCLUSION
We hold that the
  Plan standards for MRI services are not violative of Â§ 44-7-180.Â  Additionally,
  the Boardâ€™s conclusion that CCMCâ€™s need for an â€œavailableâ€ MRI unit could only
  be met by a fixed, onsite MRI is supported by substantial evidence.Â  However,
  the Board erred by finding compliance with the project review criteria did not
  have to be met in light of the Plan standards for MRI services.Â  We reverse the
  CON award and remand for a determination on the sole issue whether CCMCâ€™s
  application complies with the project review criteria set forth in the Plan.
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1] The State Health Plan is required by the South
  Carolina Certificate of Need and Health Facilities Licensure Act, S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§Â§ 44-7-110, et seq. (2002) (â€œCON Actâ€).Â  The Plan contains
  specific standards and information for health care facilities and health care
  equipment, and it must be prepared and presented for approval to the Board at
  least once every two years.Â  The 2003 State Health Plan governed CCMCâ€™s CON
  application.
[2] Section 44-7-180(B)(4) requires the State Health Plan
  to include a general statement as to the project review criteria considered
  most important in evaluating CON applications for each type of facility,
  service, and equipment.Â  The four project review criteria identified in the
  2003 Plan for MRI facilities were: (a) community need documentation; (b)
  distribution (accessibility); (c) acceptability; and (d) cost containment.
[3] Appellantâ€™s first argument is not specific to CCMCâ€™s
  CON application.Â  Appellant essentially asserts that because the 2003 Plan
  violated the CON Act, no CON for an MRI could have been lawfully awarded to any
  applicant.
[4] Appellant also claims that the Board should have made
  factual findings regarding whether the MRI standards contained in the Plan
  comply with Â§ 44-7-180(B)(2) and (3).Â  The issue whether the Plan standards
  satisfy the statutory requirements is a legal conclusion based on statutory
  interpretation principles.Â  Thus, no factual findings are necessary to
  determine compliance with Â§ 44-7-180(B).Â  
[5] The Plan ranks the relative importance of project
  review criteria, as required by Â§ 44-7-180(4), for MRI service as: (a)
  community need documentation; (b) distribution (accessibility); (c)
  acceptability; and (d) cost containment.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Brendalee
      Ables, Petitioner,
				v.
				Michael
      Gladden, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Darlington County
Â Roger E. Henderson, Family Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26518
Submitted April 1, 2008 - Refiled July 14,
  2008
AFFIRMED IN PART AS MODIFIED; 
REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED

	
		
			
				Holly
  Palmer Beeson, of Baker, Ravenel & Bender, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Newton I. Howle, Jr., of Darlington, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  WALLER: In 2005, petitioner Brendalee
  Ables filed the instant action against her former husband, respondent Michael
  Gladden, seeking reimbursement of medical expenses, health insurance premiums,
  educational expenses, work-related child care expenses, and a retroactive
  increase in child support.Â  The family court awarded petitioner $305.69 in
  medical expenses, and a $300 reimbursement for a health insurance credit given
  to respondent between 2003 and 2005 when he had not actually maintained
  insurance coverage for the child.Â  However, the family court denied
  petitionerâ€™s remaining requests primarily on the basis on untimeliness.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed, finding that the family
  court properly denied petitionerâ€™s claims based on laches.Â  Ables v. Gladden,
  Op. No. 2006-UP-420 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Dec. 19, 2006).Â  This Court granted petitionerâ€™s request for a writ of
  certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision.[1] 
FACTS
In 1992, petitioner
  and respondent were divorced in Tokyo, Japan.Â  The Japanese divorce decree
  awarded petitioner sole custody of the coupleâ€™s daughter, who was born on March
  29, 1987.Â  Respondent was ordered to pay child support in the amount of $842
  per month from June 1992 until August 1992; $667 per month from September 1992
  until respondent separated from the military; and $378 per month thereafter.Â 
  By 1993, respondent and petitioner had both returned to the United States.Â  Respondent moved to North Carolina, and petitioner moved to South Carolina.Â 
  Petitioner enrolled the child in private school in South Carolina.[2]
In 1994, a North Carolina court issued an order[3] which provided that respondent pay $46 per week in child support and provide
  health insurance coverage for the child when â€œavailable at a reasonable cost.â€Â 
  The order stated that health insurance â€œis defined to be reasonable in cost if
  it is employment related or other group insurance.â€Â  In addition, the order
  provided that if respondent failed to obtain health insurance coverage, he
  would be liable for any medical expenses incurred.
In 1997, petitioner
  sent a certified letter to respondent (who at that time lived in South Carolina) requesting payment for child support, out-of-pocket medical costs, daycare
  expenses, and educational expenses.Â  Respondent signed for the letter but did
  not respond.
In 1998, the South
  Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS), on behalf of petitioner, filed a
  Notice of Registration of the Japanese Divorce Decree in the South Carolina
  family court.Â Â  The family court, however, ruled the 1994 North Carolina Order
  was the proper order to register in South Carolina.Â  The court ordered
  respondent to pay the $46 per week, plus another $10 per week for arrears.Â  
Several other orders
  relating to the enforcement of child support were thereafter issued by the
  family court, including orders which increased and decreased the amount of
  support, set a weekly amount for arrearages, readjusted the method of payment
  for medical expenses, and garnished respondentâ€™s wages. 
Specifically
  regarding medical expenses, the 2002 family court order stated the following:Â  

	[Petitioner] provides health insurance at
  no cost.Â  [Petitioner] will be responsible for the first $250.00 of non-covered
  medical expenses per calendar year.Â  Additional expenses in excess of $250.00
  will be prorated [between petitioner and respondent:]Â  73% by [respondent,] 27%
  by [petitioner].Â  [Petitioner] will provide proof of expenses within 10 days of
  being incurred.Â  [Respondent] will have 30 days to pay the costs.

In 2005, respondent
  filed a motion to terminate ongoing support based upon the child reaching the
  age of majority.Â  At all times between 1998 and March 2005, petitioner had been
  represented by attorneys from DSS.Â  At the March 30, 2005 hearing, petitioner
  raised issues regarding reimbursement for medical expenses, daycare expenses,
  and health insurance coverage.Â  In its April 8, 2005 order, the family court
  found these issues were not properly raised because they were â€œnot within the
  assignment or duties ofâ€ DSS.Â  Nevertheless, the family court â€œreservedâ€ the
  resolution of those issues â€œfor a future hearing on her own,â€ i.e., in a
  separate action brought by petitioner.Â  The family court terminated ongoing
  child support as of March 29, 2005, because of the child turning 18, but
  ordered respondent to continue paying the $6,812.31 in arrears at a weekly rate
  of $101.79, until paid in full.  
In June 2005,
  petitioner filed the instant action against respondent which specifically
  requested, inter alia:Â  (1) a retroactive increase in child support for
  the period of time from 1998 until 2002 based on respondentâ€™s failure to report
  increases in salary; (2) reimbursement for various medical expenses, health
  insurance premiums, and work-related daycare expenses; and (3) increased child
  support from 2003 through 2005 based on an improper credit given to respondent
  for health care premiums.[4]
A hearing was held
  on October 18, 2005, at which petitioner claimed she was owed payments for
  various un-reimbursed medical, daycare and educational expenses incurred during
  the childâ€™s minority.Â  With the exception of one medical expense for a root
  canal and an adjustment because of the health care credit improperly given to
  respondent, the family court denied as untimely petitionerâ€™s various requests
  for retroactive payments. 
On appeal, the Court of Appeals
  held that â€œthe record supports the family courtâ€™s decision that lachesâ€ barred
  petitionerâ€™s claims.Â  Specifically, the Court of Appeals noted petitioner
  â€œfailed to bring any formal adjudicatory proceeding against [respondent] until
  2005, despite believing [respondent] was responsible for expenses and support
  since 1994.â€Â  The Court of Appeals further found that petitionerâ€™s delay was
  unreasonable, in part because petitioner and respondent were â€œinvolved in
  multiple court proceedings between 1999 and 2005 regarding issues surrounding
  [respondentâ€™s] child support payments.â€Â  Finally, the Court of Appeals found
  respondent would be prejudiced by petitionerâ€™s request for the â€œlarge amountâ€
  of $26,995.39.
ISSUES

	1.Â  In light of this Courtâ€™s opinion in Strickland
  v. Strickland, 375 S.C. 76, 650 S.E.2d 465 (2007), is laches no longer a
  viable defense when there is court order for child support?Â  
	2.Â  Did the Court of Appeals err in
  finding petitionerâ€™s claims childcare and private school expenses were barred
  by the doctrine of laches?
	3.Â  Did the Court of Appeals err in not
  awarding petitioner $660 for the improper credit given to respondent for health
  insurance premiums?

DISCUSSION
Standard of Review
In
  appeals from the family court, this Court has jurisdiction to find facts in
  accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  E.g., Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102 (2005).Â 
  This broad scope of review does not, however, require the appellate court to
  disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).Â  
1.Â  Strickland v. Strickland
In Strickland v. Strickland,
  375 S.C. 76, 650 S.E.2d 465 (2007), we held that laches is not a defense to a
  claim for the enforcement of an alimony award.Â  Petitioner argues that the
  ruling in Strickland logically extends to the enforcement of a child
  support order.Â  We agree.[5]
Laches
  is an equitable doctrine defined as â€œneglect for an unreasonable and
  unexplained length of time, under circumstances affording opportunity for
  diligence, to do what in law should have been done.â€Â  Hallums v. Hallums, 296 S.C. 195, 198, 371 S.E.2d 525, 527 (1988).Â  â€œWhether a claim is barred by
  laches is to be determined in light of facts of each case, taking into
  consideration whether the delay has worked injury, prejudice, or disadvantage to the other
  party; delay alone in assertion of a right does not constitute laches.â€ Â Id. at 198-99, 371 S.E.2d at 527-28.
In Hallums,
  this Court found that the doctrine of laches barred the motherâ€™s claim for
  retroactive child support.Â  In that case, however, there had been no
  adjudicated divorce and no court-ordered child support.Â  The mother first
  raised the issue of child support as a counterclaim, some 22 years after the
  father had first petitioned for a divorce, and at a time after the child had
  reached the age of majority.Â  
In Strickland,
  however, the Court had before it a case which involved a family court order
  awarding alimony.Â  The Court adopted the reasoning ofÂ  Jefferson Pilot Life
    Ins. Co. v. Gum, 302 S.C. 8, 393 S.E.2d 180 (1990), which found where a court order fixed an obligation,
      the doctrine of laches could not be applied to undo the obligation.Â  Exporting
  the Jefferson Pilot analysis to the alimony context, the Strickland  Court stated the following:

	In our opinion, this Courtâ€™s reasoning in Jefferson
  Pilot is equally applicable to a family court award of alimony.Â  Although the equitable nature of laches generally
  comports with the family courtâ€™s equitable jurisdiction in determining support
  and maintenance between former spouses, the concept of â€œinexcusable delayâ€ in
  the laches defense is inconsistent with the
  judicial authority inherent in a court order.Â  Because court orders awarding
  support and maintenance do not have an expiration date,
  allowing a party to avoid compliance based solely on the oblique notion of
  delay only serves to undermine the authority of the court.Â  See also
	Stephens
    v. Hamrick, [358 S.E.2d 547, 549 (N.C. Ct. App. 1987)] (holding that the
  doctrine of laches does not bar the enforcement of a court order for child
  support because â€œthe obligation to furnish support is continuous [and
  therefore] a lapse of time will not be a bar to commencement of an enforcement
  action.â€).Â  Accordingly, we hold that laches is not a defense to a claim for
  the enforcement of an alimony award.

Strickland, 375 S.C. at 83-84, 650 S.E.2d at 469-70.
We agree with
  petitioner that the reasoning in Strickland and Jefferson Pilot should apply with equal force to cases involving a child support order.Â  In Strickland,
  we cited a North Carolina case which involved a North Carolina mother trying to
  enforce a South Carolina child support order.Â  See Stephens v.
    Hamrick, supra.Â  The North Carolina Court of Appeals clearly held
  that because the child support obligation is continuous, the doctrine of laches does not apply to bar enforcement of
  a child support order.Â  Id.; see also South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Lowman, 269 S.C. 41, 48, 236 S.E.2d 194,
  196 (1977) (the duty of child support is a continuing obligation).
Accordingly, the
  doctrine of laches does not apply in the instant case to petitionerâ€™s claims
  for retroactive child support, health
  insurance premiums, and medical expenses.[6]
Although
  the Strickland Court disallowed laches in cases involving an alimony
  order, it nevertheless held that equitable
  estoppel could apply.Â  The Court explained that equitable estoppel â€œappropriately
  balances principles of equity and judicial authority when the underlying facts
  of a case call into question the equity of enforcing a court order.â€Â  Strickland, 375
  S.C. at 84, 650 S.E.2d at 470.Â  The Court outlined the various elements of the
  estoppel claim as follows:

	The
  elements of equitable estoppel as related to the party being estopped are: (1)
  conduct which amounts to a false representation, or conduct which is calculated
  to convey the impression that the facts are otherwise than, and inconsistent
  with, those which the party subsequently attempts to assert; (2) the intention
  that such conduct shall be acted upon by the other party; and (3) actual or
  constructive knowledge of the real facts. The party asserting estoppel must
  show:Â  (1) lack of knowledge, and the means of knowledge, of the truth as to
  the facts in question; (2) reliance upon the conduct of the party estopped; and (3) a
  prejudicial change of position in reliance on the conduct of the party being
  estopped.

Id. at 84-85, 650 S.E.2d at 470.
Petitioner asserts
  there is no evidence she should be equitably estopped from enforcing
  respondentâ€™s court-ordered obligations regarding health insurance premiums,
  medical expenses, and retroactive child support.Â  We agree.
As evidenced by the numerous orders
  in the record, petitioner consistently pursued respondent for child support and
  medical expenses.Â  Her claims go at least as far back as 1997 when she sent a
  certified letter to respondent demanding various expenses.Â  The 1994 North Carolina order, which made respondent responsible for child support and health
  insurance/medical expenses, was registered in South Carolina in 1998.Â  The
  record also reveals: (1) a 2002 order which set child support at $102 per week,
  plus $20 per week for arrears, and also set out the above-discussed formula for
  respondentâ€™s obligations regarding medical expenses; (2) a 2003 order which
  reduced the child support obligation to $62 per week, plus the $20 for arrears;
  and (3) a 2004 order which increased child support to $81.79 per week, plus $20
  for arrears.
The evidence therefore is
  undeniable petitioner never made any assurances or representations to
  respondent that he was not responsible for the court-ordered obligations
  regarding child support and medical expenses.Â  Thus, petitioner is not
  equitably estopped from asserting her claims regarding retroactive child
  support, health insurance, and medical expenses.
A.  Retroactive Child
  Support
â€œThe
  decision to order retroactive support rests within the
  sound discretion of the family court and should not be reversed absent an abuse
  of discretion by the family court.â€Â  Thornton v. Thornton, 328
  S.C. 96, 115, 492 S.E.2d 86, 96 (1997).Â  Furthermore, the family court is â€œempowered
  to modify child support upon a proper showing of a change in either the
  childâ€™s needs or the supporting parentâ€™s financial ability.â€Â  Henderson v.
    Henderson, 298 S.C. 190, 196, 379 S.E.2d 125, 129 (1989) (emphasis
  added).Â  The party seeking the modification has the burden to show changed
  circumstances.Â  Upchurch v. Upchurch, 367 S.C. 16, 26, 624 S.E.2d 643,
  648 (2006).
Here,
  the family court relied on laches and therefore did not make a decision on the
  facts.Â  In our opinion, the evidence presented by petitioner at the hearing simply
  does not support her claim for retroactive child support, and therefore, we affirm
  the denial of retroactive child support.Â  Wooten v. Wooten, supra (in appeals from the family court, this Court may find facts in accordance with
  its own view of the preponderance of the evidence).Â  
Petitioner
  testified at the hearing that respondent was making at least ten percent more
  than his reported $910 per month between 1994 and 1998, and that when the child
  support was increased in 2002, his â€œincome had significantly increased over the
  last time [she] received [a] child support increase.â€ However, our review of
  the record reveals that these are assumptions made by petitioner which were not
  supported by any specific evidence.[7]Â 
  Therefore, we find petitioner failed to carry her burden of proof for a
  retroactive increase in child support.Â  Cf. Upchurch v. Upchurch,
  367 S.C. at 26, 624 S.E.2d at 648 (â€œgeneral testimony regarding increased
  expenses, without specific evidentiary support, is an insufficient showing of
  changed circumstancesâ€).
B.  Health Insurance Premiums
  and Medical Expenses
Petitioner also
  claims she is entitled to $8,035.14 for un-reimbursed health insurance premiums
  and out-of-pocket medical expenses.Â  It appears from the documentation provided
  by petitioner at the hearing that this sum primarily represents health care
  insurance premiums that were paid from 1994 though 2005.Â  The only exception
  appears to be a dental expense related to a root canal for $668.75.
The family court
  ordered respondent to pay petitioner $305.69 of the root canal expense based on
  the formula set out in the 2002 order.[8]Â 
  Curiously, petitioner has not, in any of the subsequent filings, even mentioned
  this award.Â  Moreover, respondent has not submitted any filings at either
  appellate level, so this award is the law of the case.Â  E.g., Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 65, 624 S.E.2d 649, 653-54 (2006) (an unappealed ruling
  is the law of the case).
Thus, the only remaining
  issue is whether petitioner is entitled to be reimbursed for monies spent for
  health insurance premiums.Â  We find she is not.Â  The 1994 North Carolina order
  specified that respondent was to provide health insurance coverage for the
  child when â€œavailable at a reasonable cost,â€ and defined that to mean health
  insurance that â€œis employment related or other group insurance.â€Â 
  Significantly, however, this order also provided that if respondent failed to
  obtain health insurance coverage, he would be liable for any medical expenses
  incurred.Â  Given that there was never a court order in place that absolutely required respondent to pay for health insurance, petitioner cannot now claim she must be
  reimbursed for those costs.
In sum, we hold the
  doctrine of laches does not apply to petitionerâ€™s claims for retroactive child
  support and medical related expenses; therefore, it was error to bar these
  claims on that basis.Â  Moreover, we find petitioner is not equitably estopped
  from pursuing these claims.Â  However, on the merits, petitioner failed to carry
  her burden of proof that she was entitled to either a retroactive increase in
  child support or reimbursement for health care premiums paid between 1994 and
  2005.Â  Thus, the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision upholding the family courtâ€™s denial
  of these particular claims is affirmed as modified.
2.Â  Childcare and Private School ExpensesÂ Â Â Â Â  
Petitioner next
  argues that as to her additional claims for childcare and private school
  expenses, the Court of Appeals erred in finding, on the merits, that laches
  bars these claims.[9]
Laches
  may be established if there is an unreasonable and unexplained delay in
  asserting a legal claim.Â  Hallums v. Hallums, 296 S.C. at 198-99, 371
  S.E.2d at 527-28.Â  In order to prove the affirmative defense of laches, the
  burden is on respondent to establish (1) delay, (2) unreasonable delay, and (3)
  prejudice.Â  Id.Â  Additionally, â€œ[t]he inquiry into the applicability of
  laches is highly fact-specific and each case must be judged by its own
  merits.â€Â  Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 216, 603 S.E.2d 598,
  602 (Ct. App. 2004).
Petitioner asserts
  that her alleged delay in pursuing these claims was neither unreasonable nor
  unexplained.Â  According to petitioner, she believed that DSS was seeking these
  expenses on her behalf throughout the time it was acting as her attorney for
  the child support enforcement actions.Â  Upon learning from the family court at
  the March 30, 2005, hearing that she was unable to present these requests,
  petitioner retained private counsel and filed the instant action on June 23,
  2005.[10]Â 
  Thus, petitioner maintains there was no delay, or at the very least, not an
  unexplained or unreasonable delay.
We agree.Â  Although
  it appears these claims were not formally asserted in the family court prior to
  2005, the record shows that at least as far back as 1997, petitioner was
  attempting to collect childcare and educational expenses.Â  Cf. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Holden, 319 S.C. 72, 459 S.E.2d 846 (1995) (where
  mother continually asked father to pay child support, no unreasonable delay
  established for laches).Â  Moreover, the family courtâ€™s April 2005 order reflects
  that petitioner believed DSS was in a capacity to pursue these claims for her,
  when it fact that agency was not. Â Thus, we reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™
  holding that petitioner unreasonably delayed bringing a legal claim for the
  past childcare and educational expenses.
On the merits, the
  family court did not make any factual findings regarding petitionerâ€™s claims
  for expenses related to childcare and private school.Â  See Rule 26(a),
  SCRFC (â€œAn order or judgment pursuant to an adjudication in a domestic
  relations case shall set forth the specific findings of fact and conclusions of
  law to support the courtâ€™s decision.â€). Â As to the claim for private school
  expenses, the family court denied the request based on laches and the
  legal conclusion that â€œabsent extremely unusual circumstances, this Court does
  not require non-custodial parents to pay for private school costs.â€ 
On
  the issue of private school tuition, we find our cases turn on the facts of
  each case, not necessarily â€œextremely unusual circumstances.â€Â  See, e.g., Rabon v. Rabon, 288 S.C. 338, 342 S.E.2d 605 (1986) (where the
  Court ordered an increase in child support to cover private school costs after
  mother moved from Florence to Columbia and decided to enroll the four children
  at Heathwood Hall).Â  Thus, the family court should evaluate this claim on the
  facts presented.Â  
Accordingly,
  a remand is necessary on the issue of whether petitioner is entitled to be
  reimbursed for any portion of the childcare and private school expenses
  incurred during the childâ€™s minority.Â  
3.  Health Insurance Premium Credit
At the family court level, petitioner alleged
  respondent was credited for paying health insurance premiums between 2003 and
  2005 when in fact he did not actually provide coverage for the child.Â  The
  family court therefore found the following:

	According to the South Carolina Child
  Support Guidelines, if the credit for the insurance premium is removed for the
  period of time in question, [respondent] should have been paying $67.00 a week
  rather than the $62 he was actually paying.Â  Sixty payments were made during
  this period, and [respondent] will therefore be required to reimburse
  [petitioner] $300.00.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Petitioner contends, however, that
  because respondentâ€™s child support obligation was adjusted by $44 per month,
  she should have received $11 back for the 60 weekly payments, for a total of
  $660.00.Â  
We find the family
  court correctly calculated the amount.Â  Although the child support worksheet
  shows that respondent was indeed credited with $44 for a health insurance
  premium, it does not necessarily follow that his total obligation was thereby
  reduced by the same amount.Â  The Court of Appeals correctly noted that
  petitionerâ€™s claim did not at all reference the appropriate child support
  guidelines.Â  See S.C. Ann. Regs. Â§Â§ 114-1710 & 114-4720 (Supp.
  2007).
Because the family court correctly
  addressed this issue and the Court of Appeals affirmed, there is no error on
  this issue.
CONCLUSION
We affirm in part,
  as modified, the denial of petitionerâ€™s claims regarding retroactive child
  support, health insurance, and medical expenses.Â  As to petitionerâ€™s claims for
  private school costs and childcare, we reverse the decision that these claims
  are barred by laches and remand to the family court for a resolution on the
  merits. Â Finally, we affirm the Court of Appealsâ€™ holding that the family
  correctly calculated the award resulting from respondent being improperly
  credited with paying health insurance premiums between 2003 and 2005.
AFFIRMED IN PART
  AS MODIFIED; REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, J., concur. PLEICONES, J., concurring in a separate opinion

JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  I concur in the result
  reached by the majority on the issue of child support, but I write separately
  because as I stated in Strickland, the defense of laches should not be
  precluded simply because of the existence of a continuing court order.Â  Thus, I
  would affirm the family courtâ€™s finding that laches bars petitionerâ€™s claims
  for health insurance premiums, medical expenses, and childcare/school expenses.
I agree with the
  majorityâ€™s conclusion that petitioner did not meet her burden in proving she
  was entitled to retroactive child support.Â  However, I would hold that laches
  and other equitable defenses may prevent a parent from collecting retroactive
  child support, even when interposed against an existing court order.Â  I
  recognize that these equitable defenses should not apply, absent extraordinary
  circumstances, when enforcement of child support is sought on behalf of the
  minor child.Â  See Garris v. Cook, 278 S.C. 622, 300 S.E.2d 483
  (1983) (a parentâ€™s wrongful act should not prejudice the minor childâ€™s right to
  support).
I would affirm the
  Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in its entirety.


[1] Respondent has not filed a brief with the Court, and
  also did not file a brief at the Court of Appeals.Â  He was, however,
  represented by private counsel at the family court level.
[2] Petitioner testified that she initially enrolled
  her daughter in private school because her daughter was used to a small student-teacher
  ratio from her Department of Defense schools in Japan, and the public schools
  had â€œmuch largerâ€ classrooms.
[3] The order is entitled â€œVoluntary Support Agreement
  and Approval by Court.â€Â  Petitioner is listed as the â€œPerson Enforcing Support
  Obligation.â€Â  
[4] We note that in petitionerâ€™s complaint, she asserted
  that she â€œconsented to [respondentâ€™s] motion to file a new action to address
  the unresolved issues in the April 8, 2005 Order as well as other matters
  requested by [petitioner] in order to provide [respondent] with an opportunity
  to respond.â€Â  Respondent admitted this allegation in his answer.
[5] We recognize the Court of Appeals was decided in
  December 2006, some eight months before this Courtâ€™s decision in Strickland.
[6] Petitioner acknowledges that because her claims for
  daycare and educational expenses were never the subject of a prior court order,
  the Strickland analysis does not apply to those requests.Â  She instead
  argues the Court of Appeals erred in applying the laches doctrine to those
  claims.Â  See issue 2, infra.
[7] Indeed, petitioner specifically stated the following
  at the hearing:Â  â€œIâ€™m asking the court to require [respondent] to provide the
  income information.â€Â  She asserted she had â€œpersonal knowledgeâ€ regarding his
  income between March 2001 and May 2002, but presented no documentary proof of
  her claim.
[8] Petitioner was responsible for the first $250, and
  then respondent was responsible for 73% of the remainder.
[9] Unlike basic child support and medical expenses, the
  costs for childcare and private school were never the subject of a court
  order.Â  Therefore, the Strickland analysis is not directly applicable,
  and a laches defense may apply.
[10] As recounted in the Facts section, supra, the
  family courtâ€™s April 18, 2005 order specifically stated that petitionerâ€™s other
  issues were â€œreservedâ€ and would be addressed at a future hearing.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Michael Light, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Lexington County
Â Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26519
Heard May 7, 2008 - Filed July 14, 2008Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Deputy
  Chief Appellate Defender for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of the South
  Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V.
  Myers, of Lexington, for respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  MOORE:Â  Petitioner was
  convicted of murder and grand larceny.Â  He was sentenced to imprisonment terms
  of thirty years for murder and five years for grand larceny.Â  The Court of
  Appeals affirmed.Â  State v. Light, 363 S.C. 325, 610 S.E.2d 504 (Ct.
  App. 2005).Â  We now reverse.
FACTS
Petitioner was arrested during a traffic
  stop in Texas.Â  During the course of the arrest, Texas authorities discovered
  petitionerâ€™s girlfriend, Priscilla Davis (Davis), was missing, and questioned
  petitioner about her disappearance.Â  Petitioner admitting killing Davis.Â  In his statement, petitioner told Texas authorities that he emerged from the
  bathroom in his home to find Davis holding a long strand of brown hair and his
  .22 rifle.[1]Â 
  Davis accused petitioner of having another woman in the house, which
  petitioner denied.Â  He stated in a recorded statement:

	She went to acting a fool and called me a
  liar.Â  And the only thing I could think of, I was - I tried to distract her.Â  I
  remember swinging my left arm, I think it was, to get the rifle out of her
  hand.Â  When I did, all I can tell you, it went off.Â  Honestly, I didnâ€™t even
  think it hit her.
	Then she fell.Â  I thought it might have
  just grazed her in the shoulder.Â  So I ran out the back door to go get help
  because I donâ€™t have a telephone.Â  I ran back to her and she wasnâ€™t breathing,
  and I just panicked.Â  I didnâ€™t think nobody would believe me.Â  So the only
  thing I did, I just put her in the trunk of the car; and I just took off.Â  I
  just drove and kept driving. 


The Texas Ranger
  who interviewed petitioner testified petitioner did not claim that Davis pointed the rifle at him or that she threatened to shoot him.Â  He also testified
  petitioner later altered his story, admitting he took the rifle from Davis before it was fired.Â  The Ranger testified petitioner told him â€œthe rifle was in my
  hand when it went off, I will not deny that.Â  I took it from her.Â  It was
  either her or me.Â  I could have run, like I told them; but I didnâ€™t really
  think about it.â€Â  In his statement, petitioner stated they were standing face
  to face when the shooting occurred.
The
  State presented evidence from a firearms expert, who testified there was no
  gunshot residue around the entrance wound in Davisâ€™ chest.[2]Â  The expert testified he believed the
  shot was consistent with a distant shot of about thirty to fifty inches.Â  The
  Stateâ€™s pathologist testified the angle of the bullet wound through Davisâ€™ body made it likely Davis was sitting or kneeling when shot.Â  He testified the
  wound was consistent with a purposeful shooting and inconsistent with an
  accidental shooting.
After
  the State finished its case in chief, the State argued petitioner was not entitled
  to a self-defense charge because there was no evidence petitioner was in danger
  of losing his life or of sustaining serious bodily injury.Â  Petitioner argued
  that, at the time of the shooting, he was still â€œunder the influence of the
  initial aggressive act he contends was committed by the victim.â€Â  The trial
  judge delayed his ruling until after petitioner presented his case.
At
  trial, petitioner testified Davis had been acting jealous and following him for
  several weeks before the incident.Â  Petitioner made this same claim in his
  earlier statement to police.Â  He testified she told him that if she ever caught
  him with another woman, â€œitâ€™s going to be messy.â€Â  Petitioner testified the
  morning of the incident[3] he left to get breakfast for Davis.Â  After returning, he came out of the
  bathroom and found her holding a long brown hair[4] and his .22 rifle, stating she believed petitioner had another woman in the
  house.Â  He testified:

	She was pointing [the gun] at me and screaming and
  hollering and accusing me as usual.Â  I asked her, â€œWhat the heck is wrong with
  you, you know?Â  There has . . . not been another woman in this house.â€
	She just kept on and on, screaming and screaming at me.Â 
  I was afraid she was going to shoot me.Â  So during the screaming -- and my
  living room is very small.Â  Yâ€™all have seen that.Â  Between the two couches is
  where this happened.
	The only thing I remember, I did try -- I took my left
  hand to knock it away, try to push it away from me.Â  Than [sic] after I jerked
  it away from her, I did stumble back several feet, you know, after jerking it.Â 
  The weapon discharged but it was not intentionally [sic].Â  
	Q.  Was that in your hands?
	A.  It was in my hands.Â  I do not deny that.
	Q.  And you pulled the trigger?
	A.  Not intentionally but I had to.
	[Solicitor] Swarat:Â  Iâ€™m sorry, I couldnâ€™t hear that.Â  â€œI did not
  intentionally but I had to.â€Â  Was that what he said?
	[Petitioner]:Â  I said I didnâ€™t intentionally pull the
  trigger.
	[Counsel for petitioner]:Â  He had to have pulled the
  trigger, I think is what he said.
	Q.  No one else pulled the trigger?
	A.  There was nobody else holding the gun.Â  I mean, letâ€™s be
  logical.Â  It was just me and her there.Â  But after I jerked the weapon out of
  her hand it [fired] . . . .

At trial,
  petitioner testified he and Davis were not standing face to face.Â  He stated, â€œwhen
  you are arguing like that . . . There is a lot of movement going on. . . . she
  was crouched down.â€
Petitioner
  further stated, â€œAfter we fought over the rifle, jerked it away from her, still
  screaming and hollering at each other, I think she stopped - scooted down some,
  . . . The rifle did go off in our argument.â€
Following
  the conclusion of the trial, the trial judge denied petitionerâ€™s request to
  charge self-defense.Â  Petitioner also requested a charge on involuntary
  manslaughter.Â  Petitioner argued that if the jury believed petitioner wrestled
  the rifle away from Davis and subsequently wielded it in a reckless fashion,
  there would be a sufficient basis for charging involuntary manslaughter.Â  The
  trial judge refused, stating he did not see any indication of recklessness in
  petitionerâ€™s actions.Â  The trial judge charged the jury on murder, voluntary manslaughter,
  and accident.Â  The jury found petitioner guilty of murder.

ISSUES

	
		
			I. 
			Did the trial
  court err by denying petitionerâ€™s request for a jury instruction on involuntary
  manslaughter?
 
		
		
			II. 
			Did the trial
  court err by finding petitioner was not entitled to a jury instruction on
  self-defense?
		
	

DISCUSSION
I. Involuntary manslaughter
The Court of Appeals found the trial court
  properly refused to charge involuntary manslaughter.Â  The court stated there was
  no evidence petitioner handled the gun with reckless disregard for the safety
  of others.[5]Â  See State v. Reese, 370
  S.C. 31, 633 S.E.2d 898 (2006) (involuntary
  manslaughter is the unintentional killing of another without malice and while
  engaged in either:Â  (1) an unlawful act not amounting to a felony and not
  naturally tending to cause death or great bodily harm; or (2) a lawful act with
  reckless disregard for the safety of others).
Petitioner argues the Court of Appeals erred by
  finding he was not entitled to an involuntary manslaughter instruction.Â  He
  relies on the cases of State v. Burriss, 334 S.C. 256, 513 S.E.2d 104 (1999), and State v.
    Crosby, 355 S.C. 47, 584 S.E.2d 110 (2003), for support.
In State v. Burriss, 334
  S.C. 256, 513 S.E.2d 104 (1999), Burriss was attacked by the victim and
  another man.Â  After being pushed to the ground, Burriss drew a gun from his
  pocket and fired twice into the ground, causing both assailants to back away.Â 
  As Burriss was attempting to get off the ground, one of the assailants advanced
  towards Burriss, who was separated from his gun.Â  Burriss grabbed the gun and
  it accidentally fired, killing one of the assailants.Â  We held Burriss was
  entitled to a charge on involuntary manslaughter because the evidence supported
  a finding that he was lawfully armed in self-defense at the time the fatal shot
  occurred and there was evidence he handled the loaded gun in a negligent
  manner.
In State
  v. Crosby, 355 S.C. 47, 584 S.E.2d 110 (2003), Crosby claimed he was
  trying to break up a fight between three women, one of whom was the victimâ€™s
  girlfriend.Â  Crosby claimed the victim told him not to put his hands on his
  girlfriend and then charged at Crosby with his hands behind his back.Â  Crosby then pulled a gun out of his pocket and closed his eyes and pulled the trigger.Â  Crosby claimed he did not realize he had pulled the trigger.Â  We held Crosby was entitled
  to an involuntary manslaughter charge because there was ample evidence from
  which the jury could have inferred Crosby did not intentionally discharge the
  weapon.
Although petitioner
  had inconsistent stories, we find he was entitled to a charge on involuntary
  manslaughter.Â  The Court of Appeals distinguished Burriss and Crosby by finding that, although petitionerâ€™s statements support a finding he was
  lawfully armed in self-defense at the time of the shooting, there is no
  evidence of recklessness as required to warrant an involuntary manslaughter
  charge.Â  The Court of Appeals correctly found petitioner was lawfully armed in
  self-defense[6] at the time of the shooting because, according to his testimony, petitioner
  took the loaded gun from Davis who was threatening him with it.Â  There was also
  evidence petitioner recklessly handled the gun because, according to his
  testimony, it fired almost immediately after he took possession of it.Â  As
  specifically stated in Burriss, the negligent handling of a loaded gun
  will support a finding of involuntary manslaughter.Â  See also State
    v. White, 253 S.C. 475, 171 S.E.2d 712, cert. denied, 396 U.S. 987 (1969) (same).Â  Further, the fact petitioner and Davis were struggling over the
  weapon is sufficient evidence to support an involuntary manslaughter charge to
  the jury.Â  Casey v. State, 305 S.C. 445, 409 S.E.2d 391 (1991) (evidence
  of a struggle between a defendant and a victim over a weapon is sufficient for
  submission of an involuntary manslaughter instruction to the jury).Â 
  Accordingly, there was evidence to support a charge of involuntary manslaughter
  and, therefore, the trial court should have so charged the jury.Â  See State
    v. Reese, 370 S.C. 31, 633 S.E.2d 898 (2006) (if there is any evidence
  warranting a charge on involuntary manslaughter, then the charge must be
  given); State v. Hill, 315 S.C. 260, 433 S.E.2d 848 (1993) (trial court
  commits reversible error if it fails to give a requested charge on an issue
  raised by the evidence).
II. Self-defense
The Court of Appeals noted that petitioner
  testified he had disarmed Davis and had taken possession of the rifle when the
  shot was fired.Â  Under those facts, the court held Davis no longer posed any
  threat to petitioner and he could not have reasonably believed she did.Â  The
  court held the evidence demonstrated petitioner did not have the right to use
  deadly force in self-defense and the trial judge correctly refused to charge the
  jury on self-defense.
A self-defense charge is not required
  unless it is supported by the evidence.Â  State v. Goodson, 312 S.C. 278, 440 S.E.2d 370 (1994).Â  To establish self-defense in South Carolina, four elements must be present:Â  (1) the
  defendant must be without fault in bringing on the difficulty; (2) the
  defendant must have been in actual imminent danger of losing his life or
  sustaining serious bodily injury, or he must have
  actually believed he was in imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining
  serious bodily injury; (3) if his defense is based upon his belief of imminent
  danger, the defendant must show that a reasonably prudent person of ordinary
  firmness and courage would have entertained the belief that he was actually in
  imminent danger and that the circumstances were such as would warrant a person
  of ordinary prudence, firmness, and courage to strike the fatal blow in order
  to save himself from serious bodily harm or the loss of his life; and (4) the
  defendant had no other probable means of avoiding the danger.Â  State v.
    Slater, 373 S.C. 66, 644 S.E.2d 50 (2007).Â  If there is any evidence in the
  record from which it could reasonably be inferred that the defendant acted in self-defense, the defendant is entitled to
  instructions on the defense, and the trial judgeâ€™s refusal to do so is
  reversible error.Â  Id.
We find
  petitioner was entitled to a self-defense charge.Â  In a statement to police, petitioner indicated he took
  the gun from Davis and that it was â€œeither her or me.â€Â  This statement
  indicates he believed he was in imminent danger of losing his life.Â  Also,
  petitioner testified that in the preceding weeks, Davis had been acting
  jealous, following him, and had told him that if she ever caught him with
  another woman it was â€œgoing to be messy.â€Â  This evidence suggested that
  petitioner was reasonable in his belief that it was either Davisâ€™ or his life
  at stake when the struggle for the gun began.Â  Accordingly, the trial court
  erred by failing to charge self-defense given there was evidence to support the
  charge.Â  See State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 565 S.E.2d 298 (2002) (if there is any
  evidence in the record to support self-defense, the issue should be submitted
  to the jury).
A past holding of
  this Court seems to indicate that, where a defendant is claiming self-defense,
  as petitioner is here, involuntary manslaughter may not be charged. Â In State
    v. Pickens, 320 S.C. 528, 466 S.E.2d 364 (1996),[7] we held that where a defendant admits he intentionally shot his gun, but that
  he did so while acting lawfully but recklessly in defending himself, he is not
  entitled to a charge of involuntary manslaughter.Â  However, a self-defense
  charge and an involuntary manslaughter charge are not mutually exclusive, as
  long as there is any evidence to support both charges.Â  See Crosby v.
    State, 355 S.C. 47, 584 S.E.2d 110 (2003) (improper to hold that any
  evidence of an intentional shooting negates evidence from which any other
  inference may be drawn); Casey v. State, 305 S.C. 445, 409 S.E.2d 391
  (1991) (error by trial court in not charging involuntary manslaughter, even
  though the trial court charged murder, voluntary manslaughter, accident, and
  self-defense); State v. Turbeville, 275 S.C. 534, 273 S.E.2d 764 (1981)
  (defendant charged with involuntary manslaughter was not entitled to
  self-defense charge because there was no testimony concerning self-defense in
  the trial record; indicating the charge would be appropriate if there was
  testimony concerning self-defense).Â  When there is a factual issue as to
  whether the shooting was committed intentionally in self-defense or was
  committed unintentionally, then the defendant is entitled to both charges as
  there is â€œany evidenceâ€ to support each charge.Â  When there is evidence of both,
  as in this case, we find the jury is entitled to resolve the question of how
  the shooting actually occurred.
CONCLUSION
We find that, under
  the particular facts of this case, petitioner was entitled to the charges of
  self-defense and involuntary manslaughter.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the
  Court of Appeals is
REVERSED.
WALLER,
  PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate
  opinion.

Chief Justice Toal:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  I would affirm the
  conviction and hold that the trial court properly refused to charge both involuntary
  manslaughter and self-defense.
The majority finds that Petitioner was entitled to an
  involuntary manslaughter charge because there was evidence that Petitioner
  recklessly handled the gun and that Petitioner and the victim struggled over
  the gun.Â  In my opinion, the evidence does not support these findings.Â 
  According to Petitionerâ€™s own testimony, the gun discharged after he retrieved
  it from the victim, while the gun was in his possession, and as he stumbled
  backwards.Â  In my view, this testimony is not evidence that Petitioner
  recklessly handled the gun or that the gun fired during the struggle.Â  Compare State v. White, 253 S.C. 475, 171 S.E.2d 712 (1969)
  (holding that the defendantâ€™s testimony regarding the shooting provided
  sufficient evidence to warrant an inference that the victimâ€™s
  death was caused by the negligent handling of a loaded pistol); Tisdale v. State, S.C. Sup. Ct. Op. No. 26495(filed May 27, 2008) (Shearouse Adv. Sh.
  No. 22 at 21) (finding that the defendantâ€™s testimony that the gun discharged
  while he and the victim struggled over the gun supported an involuntary
  manslaughter charge).Â  Rather, I believe that this testimony presents a
  standard example of accident, on which the trial court properly instructed the
  jury.Â  See State v. Burriss, 334 S.C. 256, 262, 513 S.E.2d 104, 108 (1999)
  (holding that a defendant is entitled to a charge on accident where there is
  evidence that he armed himself in self-defense but the shooting occurs
  accidentally); State v.
    Goodson, 312 S.C. 278, 280 440 S.E.2d 370,
  372 (1994) (recognizing that for a homicide
  to be excusable on the ground of accident, it must be shown that the killing
  was unintentional, that the defendant was acting lawfully, and that due care
  was exercised in the handling of the weapon).[8]Â  Accordingly, I would hold that there is no evidence to support an
  involuntary manslaughter charge.
In my opinion, the majority also errs in holding that
  Petitioner was entitled to a self-defense charge.Â  Even assuming that
  Petitioner reasonably believed that he was in imminent danger when the victim
  first confronted him with the gun due to the victimâ€™s previous threats,
  Petitioner testified that he â€œjerkedâ€ the gun away from the victim, the victim
  was â€œcrouched downâ€ when she was shot, and that he did not intentionally pull
  the trigger. Â Thus, in my view, Petitioner was neither in imminent danger nor
  did he believe he was in imminent danger at the time he shot the victim.Â  I
  would therefore hold that the trial court properly refused to charge self-defense.Â  See State v. Bruno, 322 S.C. 534, 536, 473 S.E.2d 450, 452 (1996) (holding that the defendant was not entitled to a self-defense charge where he
  presented no evidence that he believed that he was in imminent danger when he
  shot the victim).Â  
While I agree with the majority that a self-defense
  charge and involuntary manslaughter charge are not necessarily mutually
  exclusive, there must be some evidence in the record to support the charges,
  and in my opinion, no evidence in the record supports either charge in this
  case.Â  For these reasons, I would hold that the trial court properly refused to
  give an involuntary manslaughter charge and a self-defense charge.Â  



[1]Petitioner
  always kept this rifle loaded. 
[2]Petitioner
  disposed of Davisâ€™ body in Alabama on his way to Texas.Â  He led police to her
  body after he admitted his involvement in Davisâ€™ death.
[3]The
  night before, petitioner and Davis had been at a bar until approximately 3:30
  a.m.Â  There was testimony they were not arguing or fighting and were dancing to
  slow songs.Â  There was also testimony that, when Davis and petitioner left,
  petitioner had Davis, who was crying, by the arm. 
[4]The
  brown hair and the lubricant bottle that the hair was allegedly found on were
  not recovered when petitionerâ€™s house was processed for evidence.
[5]The Court of Appeals noted petitioner argued in his
  statement of issues that the gun discharged while petitioner and Davis were
  struggling over the gun and that, as a result, it was â€œa classic case of
  involuntary manslaughter.â€Â  The court held an involuntary manslaughter charge
  would have been warranted if there was evidence the gun discharged while
  petitioner and Davis were struggling over it.Â  However, the court noted
  petitioner failed to argue the gun discharged during the course of the struggle
  in his brief; therefore, it held petitioner abandoned the issue on appeal.Â 
  We disagree that petitioner abandoned his argument.Â  Throughout his brief, petitioner discussed the struggle for the gun.
[6]The Burriss court noted that there is a difference between being lawfully armed in self-defense and acting in self-defense.Â  Burriss, 334 S.C. at
  265, n.10, 513 S.E.2d at 109, n.10.Â  At this point in the analysis, we are
  concerned only with whether petitioner had a right to be armed for purposes of
  determining whether he was engaged in a lawful act, i.e. was lawfully
  armed, and not whether he actually acted in self-defense when the shooting
  occurred. 
[7]In Pickens, Pickens and a co-defendant began shooting in self-defense when
  a group of ten to twelve people rushed them outside of a Waffle House. 
[8] I agree with the majority insofar as I believe that Petitioner had the right to
  take the weapon away from the victim.Â
