THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Freddie Eugene
      Owens, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26520
Heard June 12, 2008 - Filed July 14, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Chief
  Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, and Appellate Defender LaNelle C.
  DuRant, both of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of
  Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Assistant Attorney General J.
  Anthony Mabry, all of Columbia, and Robert Mills Ariail, of Greenville, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  Appellant appeals his
  death sentence following a second resentencing proceeding.Â  This opinion
  consolidates his appeal and the mandatory proportionality review.Â  We affirm.
Appellant was
  convicted of murder, armed robbery, using a firearm during the commission of a
  violent crime, and conspiracy to commit armed robbery, and received a death
  sentence for murder, thirty years for armed robbery, and five years for each of
  the other two offenses.Â  On his first appeal, the convictions were affirmed,
  but his death sentence reversed and his five year sentence for firearm
  possession vacated.[1]Â  State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 552 S.E.2d 745 (2001).Â  Â  Following a
  bench resentencing proceeding, appellant again received a death sentence.Â  This
  Court vacated that sentence, finding the trial judgeâ€™s comments to appellant in
  regard to his right to a jury trial constituted reversible error.Â  State v.
    Owens, 362 S.C. 175, 607 S.E.2d 78 (2004).
This second resentencing was tried to a jury which returned a death sentence, finding two
  aggravating circumstances: (1) the murder was committed in the commission of
  robbery while armed with a deadly weapon and (2) the murder was committed while
  in the commission of larceny with use of a deadly weapon.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  16-3-20(C)(a)(1)(d) and (e).Â  Appellant raises three issues on appeal.
ISSUES

	1)  Whether the trial judge erred in
  disqualifying a juror?
	2)  Whether the solicitorâ€™s closing
  argument was improper?
	3)  Whether the trial judge erred in
  admitting redacted prison disciplinary records?

ANALYSIS
Appellant conceded
  at oral argument that there was no objection at trial to the juror
  disqualification or to the closing argument.Â  Without an objection, neither of
  these issues is properly preserved for appellate review. Â E.g., State
    v. Stone, 376 S.C. 32, 655 S.E.2d 487 fn. 1 (2007) (â€œSouth Carolinaâ€™s
  strict error preservation rules are no less applicable in death penalty
  casesâ€).Â  Under these circumstances, we do not reach the merits of either
  issue.
One issue is
  preserved for review: Â Appellant contends the trial court erred in admitting a
  list of disciplinary infractions allegedly committed by appellant while in the
  Department of Corrections because its admission violated the prohibition
  against hearsay, appellantâ€™s Confrontation Clause rights, and his due process
  rights.Â  Neither the Confrontation Clause nor due process was raised to the
  trial court, and accordingly neither constitutional claim is preserved for our
  review.Â  State v. Stone, supra.Â  We address only the hearsay
  issue.
The trial judge
  permitted the State to introduce a redacted version of appellantâ€™s prison
  offenses pursuant to the business records exception to the rule against
  hearsay.Â  In so doing, he required the State to omit from the list all details
  of the incidents, and all incidents not witnessed by a prison guard or staff
  member.Â  These rulings reduced the number of incidents to 28, which were
  presented to the jury in this format[2]:

	
		
			1. 
			April 13, 2001, breaks toilet,
  sink and sprinkler
		
		
			2.
			May 26, 2001, throws hot water on
  another inmate
		
		
			3. 
			May 27, 2001, had a six and a half
  inch shank made from fencing and toothbrush
		
		
			4.
			June 14, 2001, spat on a
  correctional officer
		
		
			5.
			February 8, 2002, a 14 inch solid
  brass shank
		
		
			6.
			March 29, 2002, stabs correctional officer in the face with a 
			shank
		
		
			7.  
			June 12, 2002, stabs an inmate in the shower
		
		
			8. 
			June 15, 2002, kicks an inmate who is restrained in a restraint 
			chair
		
		
			9.   
			August 5, 2002, slaps a male nurse in the face
		
		
			10.
			August 17, 2002, throws a food tray and hits an officer in the 
			head
		
		
			11. 
			August 23, 2002, struck an officer in the face with his fist
		
		
			12. 
			October 22, 2002, hits an officer in the face with his fist
		
		
			13.
			October 23, 2002, sets fire to cell
		
		
			14. 
			December 22, 2002, shank made from fencing
		
		
			15. 
			December 30, 2002, a ten inch shank made from a push rod of the 
			sink
		
		
			16.   
			July 17, 2005, spits in the face of an officer 
		
		
			17.  
			August 26, 2005, slaps an officer in the face
		
		
			18.  
			August 31, 2005, sets fire to cell
		
		
			19.
			September 11, 2005, threatens an officer 
		
		
			20.
			January 1, 2006, a 12 inch homemade knife
		
		
			21.
			January 3, 2006, breaks cell door window with broom stick
		
		
			22. 
			January 13, 2006, throws feces on an officer, hitting him in the 
			face
		
		
			23.
			February 3, 2006, spits in the face of another inmate
		
		
			24.
			February 4, 2006, orally threatens an officer 
		
		
			25. 
			February 28, 2006, a 12 inch weapon hidden between the 
			mattresses
		
		
			26.  
			April 4, 2006, an eight and a half inch shank made from flat 
			metal sharpened at the edge and wrapped with ace bandage
		
		
			27. 
			May 1, 2006, sets fire to his mattress
		
		
			28. 
			May 20, 2006, throws coffee on an officer
		
	

Appellant
  contends the records are inadmissible hearsay because they are not trustworthy
  under Rule 803(6), SCRE.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the trial judgeâ€™s
  decision finding trustworthy those incidents witnessed by prison staff.Â  E.g., State v. Pittman, 373 S.C. 527, 647 S.E.2d 144 (2007) (admission of
  evidence with trial judgeâ€™s discretion); cf. Ohio v. Roberts, 448
  U.S. 56 (1980) overruled on other grounds Crawford v. Washington,
  541 U.S. 36 (2004) (properly administered, Rule 803(6) exceptions are among the
  safest against a confrontation-clause challenges).
Moreover,
  appellant has not asked to argue against the precedent of State v. Whipple,
  324 S.C. 43, 476 S.E.2d 683 (1996) which held that these types of prison
  disciplinary records are admissible at the sentencing phase of a capital trial
  under the Uniform Business Records as Evidence Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 19-5-510
  (the Act).Â  Id. cited with approval in State v. Holmes, 361 S.C.
  333, 605 S.E.2d 19 (2004) vacated and remanded on other grounds Holmes
    v. South Carolina, 547 U.S. 319 (2006).Â  Appellant contends that the
  continuing validity of Whipple is in doubt as that decision predates the
  adoption of the SCRE, and alleges that Rule 803(6) added a veracity requirement
  to the admissibility requirements for a business record.Â  Contrary to
  appellantâ€™s position, trustworthiness is an issue under the Act, not a new
  condition created by Rule 803(6).Â  Kershaw County Depâ€™t of
    Soc. Servs. v. McCaskill, 276 S.C. 360, 278 S.E.2d 771 (1981); see also State v. Rice, 375 S.C. 302, 652 S.E.2d 409 (Ct. App. 2007).
Appellant
  failed to show an abuse of discretion in the trial judgeâ€™s decision to admit
  the redacted prison disciplinary incidents.Â  State v. Pittman, supra; State v. Whipple, supra.
Proportionality Review
Pursuant to S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(c) (2003), we have conducted a proportionality review and
  find the death sentence was not the result of passion, prejudice, or any other
  arbitrary factor.Â  Furthermore, a review of other decisions demonstrates that
  appellantâ€™s sentence was neither excessive nor disproportionate.Â  See State v. Humphries, 325 S.C. 28, 479 S.E.2d 52 (1996) (murder of
  convenience store operator in the commission of attempted armed robbery); State
    v. Simpson, 325 S.C. 37, 479 S.E.2d 57 (1996) (murder of convenience store
  operator in the commission of armed robbery).

CONCLUSION
Appellantâ€™s capital
  sentence is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1] Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-490(A), no firearm sentence may be imposed where
  the defendant receives a death sentence or life sentence without parole for the
  violent crime.Â  The vacation of appellantâ€™s sentence was conditional: if
  appellant were ultimately to receive a life sentence for murder, then the five
  year sentence would be reimposed.
[2] We have made one minor alteration in choosing to omit the names of the victims
  from the list.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Petitioner,
				v.
				Jacqueline
      Mekler, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26521
Heard May 8, 2008 - Filed July 14, 2008 
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant
  Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia, and David Michael Pascoe,
  Jr., of Orangeburg, for Petitioners.
				Deputy Chief Appellate Defender for Capital Appeals Robert M.
  Dudek, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate
  Defense, of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â Â Â Â Â Â  A jury convicted
  Jacqueline Mekler (Mekler) of murder, and she received a sentence of thirty
  years.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded
  for a new trial.Â  State v. Mekler, 368 S.C. 1, 626 S.E.2d 890 (Ct. App.
  2005).Â  We granted the Stateâ€™s petition for certiorari and now affirm.
FACTS
Mekler
  and her neighbor, Robette Spires (Spires), were visiting on Meklerâ€™s front
  porch one evening when Spiresâ€™ husband, Bubba, (Victim) drove his truck into
  Meklerâ€™s yard.Â  Victim began screaming and yelling at Spires because Spires was
  not at home and because Spires had not called him.Â  Mekler and Victim began
  yelling at each other, and Mekler asked Victim to leave.Â  Victim left in his
  truck and drove to Spiresâ€™ residence, which was one block away from Meklerâ€™s
  home.[1]
A few minutes
  later, Victim walked back to Meklerâ€™s house.Â  According to Mekler, Victim
  approached the porch, yelling and screaming in the same manner as before he
  left.Â  Meklerâ€™s dog was attached to a chain on the porch and began barking at
  Victim.Â  The chained dog then ran out on the porch steps towards Victim,
  halting his progress.Â  Mekler grabbed the dog and noticed a knife in Victimâ€™s
  hand.Â  Victim told Mekler the knife was for the dog.Â  After subduing the dog,
  Mekler stepped inside her house and grabbed her shotgun, which she had placed
  near the front door after Victim initially left.
Mekler testified
  that after she stepped on the porch with the shotgun, she continued to ask
  Victim to leave, but he continued to stand in the yard near the steps with the
  knife and threatened to come up on the porch and get Spires.Â  Mekler testified
  that she pulled the hammer back on the shotgun and positioned the gun at her
  hip to do so.Â  Mekler recounted that when she cocked the gun, the Victim leaned
  and the gun fired, but she did not remember pulling the trigger.Â  In three
  separate statements to various law enforcement personnel and throughout her
  trial testimony, Mekler maintained that she did not intentionally pull the
  trigger.
At trial, defense
  counsel requested a jury charge on self-defense, accident, and involuntary
  manslaughter.Â  The trial court refused to charge the jury on involuntary
  manslaughter and accident.Â  The jury convicted Mekler of murder, and the judge
  sentenced her to thirty years imprisonment.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed on
  the grounds that: (1) the trial court failed to charge involuntary manslaughter;
  and (2) the trial court failed to admit specific details of a prior act of
  violence by Victim.Â  
ISSUES

	I.  Did
  the Court of Appeals err in reversing Meklerâ€™s conviction due to the failure to
  charge the jury on involuntary manslaughter?
	II.  Did
  the Court of Appeals err in reversing Meklerâ€™s conviction based on the trial
  judgeâ€™s denial of Meklerâ€™s request to introduce specific details of a prior
  domestic violence incident between Spires and Victim?

ANALYSIS
I.  Involuntary
  manslaughter charge
The State argues
  the Court of Appeals erred in reversing respondentâ€™s conviction based on the
  trial judgeâ€™s failure to charge the jury on involuntary manslaughter.Â  We
  disagree.
Involuntary
  manslaughter is defined as (1) the unintentional killing of another without
  malice but while engaged in an unlawful activity not naturally tending to cause
  death or great bodily harm; or (2) the unintentional killing of another without
  malice but while engaged in a lawful activity with reckless disregard for the
  safety of others.Â  State v. Burriss, 334 S.C. 256, 264-265, 513 S.E.2d
  104, 109 (1999).Â  The negligent handling of a loaded gun will support a charge
  of involuntary manslaughter.Â  Id. (citing State v. White, 253
  S.C. 475, 171 S.E.2d 712 (1969)).Â  A trial court should refuse to charge the
  lesser-included offense of involuntary manslaughter only where there is no
  evidence the defendant committed the lesser offense.Â  State v. Crosby,
  355 S.C. 47, 51, 584 S.E.2d 110, 112 (2003).
We hold that the
  Court of Appeals correctly held that there was evidence to support a finding
  that Mekler was lawfully armed in self-defense and did not intentionally
  discharge the shotgun.Â  Moreover, evidence exists to support a jury finding
  that Meklerâ€™s recklessness caused the gun to fire.
The following
  evidence adduced at trial supports the involuntary manslaughter charge: (1) the
  three statements given by Mekler and introduced at trial in which Mekler stated
  she did not remember pulling the trigger or the shotgun discharging; (2)
  Meklerâ€™s trial testimony in which she stated she did not remember pulling the
  trigger and had to be told by Spires that she shot Victim; (3) Meklerâ€™s trial
  testimony in which she stated the gun was positioned at her hip so she could
  cock the hammer back and that her finger must have slipped on the trigger,
  causing the gun to fire suddenly; (4) testimony by a neighbor who looked out of
  her window right before the shot was fired and saw one of Meklerâ€™s arms down at
  her side and the other waving when she talked;[2] and (5) Meklerâ€™s insistence at trial that she did not intend to shoot Victim
  and that she was shocked when the gun fired immediately after she cocked the
  hammer.Â  
Accordingly,
  the evidence supports a finding that Mekler, lawfully armed in self-defense,
  unintentionally shot Victim while negligently handling the shotgun when her
  finger slipped on the trigger after resting the gun on her hip to cock it.Â  See Burriss, supra (negligent handling of loaded gun will support a
  finding of involuntary manslaughter).
Finally,
  a self-defense charge and an involuntary manslaughter charge are not mutually
  exclusive, as long as there is any evidence to support both charges.Â  See Casey v. State, 305 S.C. 445, 409 S.E.2d 391 (1991) (error by trial
  court in not charging involuntary manslaughter, even though the trial court
  charged murder, voluntary manslaughter, accident, and self-defense); Crosby, supra (improper to hold that any evidence of an intentional shooting
  negates evidence from which any other inference may be drawn); State v.
    Light, Op. No. Â­Â­26519 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed July 14, 2008) (Shearouse Adv.
  Sh. 29 at p. 42).
In
  this case, there was evidence from which the inference could be drawn that
  Mekler intentionally shot Victim in self-defense, and there was evidence that
  Mekler unintentionally shot Victim while acting in reckless disregard of the
  safety of others by negligently handling a loaded shotgun.Â  The jury should
  have been allowed to determine how the shooting occurred, and the Court of
  Appeals did not err by reversing and remanding for a new trial due to the trial
  courtâ€™s failure to charge involuntary manslaughter.
II.  Evidence of prior act of Victim
Because
  we affirm the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision to grant Mekler a new trial based on
  failure to charge involuntary manslaughter, it is unnecessary to address the
  second issue.Â  Whether this issue will arise on retrial and its resolution will
  depend upon the evidence and testimony presented, and it will be for the trial
  judgeâ€™s consideration.
CONCLUSION
We
  hold that Mekler was entitled to an involuntary manslaughter charge because
  evidence existed to support a finding that she was lawfully armed in
  self-defense and that her reckless handling of the shotgun resulted in the
  death of Victim.Â  Moreover, a charge of self-defense and a charge of
  involuntary manslaughter are not mutually exclusive.Â  The decision of the Court
  of Appeals is 
AFFIRMED.
MOORE, Acting Chief Justice, WALLER, J., and Acting Justices James E. Lockemy and J.
  Michelle Childs, concur.

  separate residences.Â  
[2] This supports Meklerâ€™s testimony that the gun was at
  her hip when it discharged.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
RE:Â Â  Rules Advisory Committee

ORDER

In 1985, this Court
  promulgated the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure (SCRCP), and the South
  Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure.Â  In developing these rules, this Court
  was assisted by the Ad Hoc Civil Rules Committee.Â  Since that time the Ad Hoc
  Civil Rules Committee has continued to assist this Court in its consideration
  of amendments to the SCRCP, and the advice and recommendations of the Committee
  has been invaluable.Â Â  
This Court has decided
  that having an advisory committee available to study and make recommendations
  regarding all rules that relate to the trial courts of this State and not just
  the rules of civil procedure would be appropriate.Â  Therefore, the Ad Hoc Civil
  Rules Committee is hereby disbanded and, pursuant to Article V, Â§4A, of the South Carolina
  Constitution, the South Carolina Appellate Court Rules (SCACR) is amended to add
  Rule 609.Â  This rule, which is attached to this order, creates a Rules Advisory
  Committee.Â  This amendment to the SCACR shall be effective immediately.
IT IS SO ORDERED.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

RULE 609
RULES ADVISORY COMMITTEE
(a)Â Â Â Â  Members.Â  The Rules Advisory Committee (Committee)
  shall consist of the following members who shall be
  appointed by the Supreme Court for four (4) year terms:

	(1)  a circuit court judge who shall serve as the chair of the
  Committee;
	(2)  a circuit court judge
  or a master-in-equity;
	(3)  a family court judge;
	(4)  a probate judge;
	(5)  a magistrate or
  municipal court judge;
	(6)  four active members of
  the South Carolina Bar; and,
	(7)  a non-voting reporter.

For the initial appointments,
  half of the members shall be appointed for two (2) year terms and half of the
  members shall be appointed for four (4) year terms.  In case of a vacancy
  on the Committee, the Supreme Court shall appoint a member to serve the
  remainder of the unexpired term.Â  A quorum shall consist of five members not
  counting the reporter. 
(b)Â Â Â Â  Duties.Â  The Committee shall make recommendations regarding the
  adoption or amendment of rules governing the administration of or the practice
  and procedure before the trial courts of this State.Â  This shall include, but
  is not limited to, the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, the South
  Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure, the South Carolina Rules of Family Court,
  the South Carolina Rules of Probate Court, the South Carolina Rules of
  Magistrates Court and the South Carolina Rules of Evidence.Â  Further, the Supreme
  Court may refer proposed rules or issues to the Committee for its
  consideration. Â The recommendations of the Committee shall be in writing and
  shall contain the language of any proposed rule or amendment along with an
  explanation and analysis of the recommendations made by the Committee.Â  For any
  proposed rule or amendment which must be submitted to the South Carolina
  General Assembly under Article V, Â§4A, of the South Carolina Constitution, the
  recommendations of the Committee must be submitted to the Supreme Court by October
  1st.
(c)Â Â Â Â  Subcommittees.Â  The Committee may divide itself into
  subcommittees to consider and make recommendations to the Committee.Â 
  Additionally, the Supreme Court may appoint a Special Subcommittee when it
  determines that additional personnel are necessary to study and make recommendations
  regarding a particular rule or set of rules.Â  If appointed, a Special
  Subcommittee shall make their recommendations to the Committee.
(d)Â Â Â Â  Power
  of Supreme Court.Â 
  Nothing in this Rule shall prevent the Supreme Court from promulgating a rule or
  rule amendment without submitting the matter to the Committee.Â  Further, the
  Supreme Court may refer a proposed rule or amendment to other groups for their recommendations.

title: State v. NV Sumatra Tobacco Trading
description: This case involves whether the lower court erred by finding South Carolina has personal jurisdiction over an Indonesian tobacco manufacturer for purposes of the Tobacco Escrow Fund Act and whether the lower court properly granted the State's motion for summary judgment on the merits of the action.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        State of South Carolina, Respondent,
        v.
        NV Sumatra
          Tobacco Trading, Co., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26522
Heard May 28, 2008 - Filed July 21, 2008Â  

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
        Joel W.
          Collins, Jr., Gray T. Culbreath, and Â Christian Stegmaier, of Columbia; Christopher
          L. Rissetto and Jason P. Matechak, of Washington, D.C., for appellant.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster and Assistant Deputy Attorney General J. Emory
          Smith, Jr., of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


\ACTING
  CHIEF JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Respondent (the
  State) filed a complaint alleging that appellant, NV Sumatra Tobacco Trading
  Co. (Sumatra), is a tobacco product manufacturer under the Tobacco Escrow Fund
  Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 11-47-10, et seq. (Supp. 2007).Â  The State alleged
  Sumatra had failed to make the escrow deposit and provide the certification
  required by the Act for cigarettes that had been sold in South Carolina.
\Sumatra filed an
  answer and moved to dismiss the action for lack of personal jurisdiction.Â  In a
  2003 order, the court ruled it had personal jurisdiction.Â  The parties then
  filed cross-motions for summary judgment.Â  In a 2006 order, the court granted
  the Stateâ€™s motion and denied Sumatraâ€™s motion.Â  The court found that Sumatra had failed to comply with the Escrow Fund Act and assessed a civil penalty of
  $307,630.08.Â  The court also prohibited Sumatra from selling cigarettes to South Carolina consumers for a period of two years.Â  Finally, the court ordered Sumatra to pay attorney fees of $7,875.00 and filing fees of $95.00.Â  Sumatra appeals both
  the 2003 and 2006 orders.
FACTS
Under
  the Master Settlement Agreement, a group of United States-based tobacco product
  manufacturers agreed to pay money damages to the participating states,
  including South Carolina, for Medicare and Medicaid costs incurred by the
  states in paying health care expenses of in-state cigarette smokers and for
  education and cessation programs.
\The South Carolina
  Tobacco Escrow Fund Act requires a tobacco product manufacturer having sales of
  cigarettes in this state (whether directly or through a distributor, retailer,
  or similar intermediary) to:

  (a) become a participating manufacturer, (as that term is
    defined in section II(jj) of the Master Settlement Agreement)[1] and generally perform its financial obligations under the Master Settlement
    Agreement; or
  (b)(1)
    place into a qualified escrow fund[2] by April 15 of the year following the year in question the following amounts
    (as such amounts are adjusted for inflation)--- . . . for . . . 2001 . . .:Â 
    $0.136125 per unit sold . . .

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 11-47-30
  (Supp. 2007).Â  The Act defines â€œtobacco product manufacturerâ€ to include an
  entity that

  (1) manufactures cigarettes anywhere that such manufacturer
    intends to be sold in the United States, including cigarettes intended to be
    sold in the United States through an importer . . . [or]
  (2) is the first purchaser anywhere for
    resale in the United States of cigarettes manufactured anywhere that the
    manufacturer does not intend to be sold in the United States; . . .

Â§ 11-47-20(i).
Sumatra is a
  corporation organized under the laws of the Republic of Indonesia and its
  business address is located in Indonesia.Â  Sumatra produces a number of tobacco
  products, including United brand cigarettes, the cigarettes at issue here.Â  Sumatra also sells its products on the Indonesian retail market.Â  Sumatra alleges it sells
  tobacco products destined for non-Indonesian markets solely to UNICO Trading
  Pte., Ltd. (UNICO), a Singapore corporation.Â  Sumatra alleges UNICO is not an
  agent of Sumatra or a distributor of Sumatraâ€™s products, but that UNICO acts
  entirely as an independent reseller.Â  Sumatra states that it and UNICO are
  separate legal entities with no overlapping ownership or control and that UNICO
  has no authority to bind or otherwise act on Sumatraâ€™s behalf.
Sumatra admits that
  UNICO may have sold cigarettes produced by Sumatra to Silmar Trading Ltd., a British Virgin Islands corporation.Â  Sumatra states it does not have any contractual
  relationship with Silmar Trading to sell its cigarettes in South Carolina.Â 
  Sumatra states that Silmar Trading may have engaged American Automotive
  Security Products, d/b/a F.T.S. Distributors (FTS), a United States importer based in Miami, Florida, for the purpose of selling tobacco products produced
  by Sumatra in the United States.
ISSUES

  
    I.
    Did the circuit court err by
  denying Sumatra’s motion to dismiss the complaint for lack of personal
  jurisdiction?
  
  
  
    II.
    Did the circuit court err by
  granting summary judgment to the State?
  

DISCUSSION
I. Personal jurisdiction
Sumatra argues that, when determining whether personal
  jurisdiction exists, the court erred by relying on an affidavit of Basil E.
  Battah, the president of FTS.Â  Sumatra claims the affidavit is not
  authenticated; however, this argument is not preserved for review.Â  At the 2003
  hearing, Sumatra objected to the introduction of the affidavit on the grounds
  of irrelevance and hearsay.Â  Sumatra merely mentioned the affidavit was not
  authenticated.Â  Sumatra did not raise this issue in any of its submissions to
  the lower court including the motion for reconsideration of the personal
  jurisdiction order.Â  In fact, Sumatra previously used the Battah affidavit in
  making its argument on the merits that Sumatra was not shipping to a United States distributor.Â  Therefore, Sumatraâ€™s arguments regarding the authentication of
  the Battah affidavit and its arguments regarding the alleged facial defects of
  the document are not preserved for the Courtâ€™s review.Â  See Holy Loch
  Distribs., Inc. v. Hitchcock, 340 S.C. 20, 531 S.E.2d 282 (2000)
  (to preserve an issue for appellate review, the issue must have been raised to
  and ruled upon by the trial court).Â  Given the authentication argument is not
  preserved, the fact the Battah affidavit is a duplicate rather than the
  original is of no moment.[3]Â  See Rule 1003, SCRE (a duplicate is admissible to same extent as an
  original unless (1) a genuine question is raised as to the authenticity of the
  original or (2) in the circumstances it would be unfair to admit the duplicate
  in lieu of the original).
Sumatra argues the
  court erred by denying Sumatraâ€™s motion to dismiss for lack of personal
  jurisdiction.Â  The court found that the connections of Sumatraâ€™s cigarettes,
  known as the United brand, to the United States are numerous.Â  The court cited
  to Sumatraâ€™s admission that it manufactured the United brand and owned the United States trademark for it in 2001.Â  The court noted the bill of lading attached to the
  Battah affidavit which showed a shipment of over 91,000 pounds of Sumatra
  cigarettes to the United States to FTS in December 2000.Â  The court noted the
  Department of Revenue reports that 6,868,000 United brand cigarettes were sold
  in 2001, including those shipped by FTS.Â  The court further noted that Sumatra had filed an ingredient report with the Center for Disease Control.
The 2003 court found the allegations in the complaint
  that Sumatra intended to sell cigarettes in the United States are amply
  sufficient to make the prima facie showing for jurisdiction due to the large
  volume of Sumatraâ€™s sales in South Carolina.Â  The court pointed out that
  Sumatra acknowledged that its ownership of the trademark for United brand
  cigarettes could be construed as an indication that Sumatra itself has the
  intent to sell this brand in the United States.
The 2003 court found
  that personal jurisdiction was properly asserted over Sumatra because the
  requirements of due process are met, i.e. there are sufficient minimum
  contacts by Sumatra with South Carolina such that the court has the power to
  adjudicate the action and the exercise of jurisdiction is fair.Â  The court
  stated that Sumatraâ€™s conduct has demonstrated its intent to avail itself of
  the vast, lucrative markets of each state in the United States.
The question of
  personal jurisdiction over a nonresident defendant is one which must be
  resolved upon the facts of each particular case.Â  Cockrell v. Hillerich
  & Bradsby Co., 363 S.C. 485, 611 S.E.2d 505 (2005).Â  The decision of
  the trial court will be affirmed unless unsupported by the evidence or
  influenced by an error of law.Â  Id.
Initially, the
  court properly found that the allegations in the complaint that Sumatra
  intended to sell its United brand cigarettes in South Carolina were sufficient
  to make the prima facie showing for personal jurisdiction.Â  See Cockrell, supra (at the pretrial stage, the burden of proving personal
  jurisdiction over a nonresident is met by a prima facie showing of jurisdiction
  in the complaint or in the affidavit); Mid-State Distribs., Inc. v. Century
  Importers, Inc., 310 S.C. 330, 426 S.E.2d 777 (1993) (there is no â€œother
  evidenceâ€ requirement for personal jurisdiction where the complaint itself
  demonstrates jurisdiction).Â  While the 2003 court could have stopped its
  analysis there, it chose to proceed with the more in-depth determination of
  personal jurisdiction.Â  The 2006 court found that Sumatra had not offered any reason
  for a different conclusion regarding personal jurisdiction on summary judgment.
Specific
  jurisdiction over a cause of action arising from a defendantâ€™s contacts with
  the state is granted pursuant to the long-arm statute.Â  Cockrell, supra (citing S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-803).Â  In the instant case, S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  36-2-803(1)(h) (2003)[4] applies to the facts of this case and states that a court may exercise personal
  jurisdiction over a person who acts directly or by an agent as to a cause of
  action arising from the personâ€™s production, manufacture, or distribution of
  goods with the reasonable expectation that those goods are to be used or
  consumed in this State and are so used and consumed.Â  South Carolinaâ€™s long-arm
  statute has been construed to extend to the outer limits of the due process
  clause.Â  Id.Â  Because South Carolina treats its long-arm statute as
  coextensive with the due process clause, the sole question becomes whether the
  exercise of personal jurisdiction would violate due process.Â  Id.
Due process requires that there exist minimum contacts
  between the defendant and the forum state such that maintenance of the suit
  does not offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice.Â  Id. (citing Burger King Corp. v. Rudzewicz, 471 U.S. 462 (1985)). Â Further,
  due process mandates that the defendant possess sufficient minimum contacts with the forum state, so that
  he could reasonably anticipate being haled into court there.Â  Id. (citing World-Wide Volkswagen Corp. v. Woodson, 444 U.S. 286
  (1980).Â  Without minimum contacts, the court does not have the â€œpowerâ€ to
  adjudicate the action.Â  Id. Â The court must also find that the
  exercise of jurisdiction is â€œreasonableâ€ or â€œfair.â€Â  Id.Â  If either
  prong fails, the exercise of personal jurisdiction over the defendant fails to
  comport with the requirements of due process.Â  Southern Plastics Co. v.
  Southern Commerce Bank, 310 S.C. 256, 423 S.E.2d 128 (1992).
The
  foreseeability that is critical to due process analysis is not the mere
  likelihood that a product will find its way into the forum state.Â  Rather, it
  is that the defendantâ€™s conduct and connection with the forum state are such
  that he should reasonably anticipate being haled into court there.Â  This theory
  of personal jurisdiction is known as the â€œstream of commerceâ€ theory.[5]Â  Southern Plastics Co., supra (citing World-Wide Volkswagen
  Corp., 444 U.S. at 297).
While it is true
  Sumatra is not registered to do business in South Carolina, has no office in South Carolina, and no person representing Sumatra has been in South Carolina, physical
  presence in the State is not required to establish personal jurisdiction.Â  See Southern Plastics Co., supra.Â  The dispositive issue is whether
  Sumatra possesses minimum contacts with South Carolina.
It is clear Sumatra
  has minimum contacts with the United States as a whole and, via the stream of
  commerce theory, the State has shown Sumatra has minimum contacts with South Carolina.Â  The facts pointing to minimum contacts are as follows:Â  (1) Sumatra admits
  it manufactured the United brand cigarettes; (2) Sumatra admits it owns the
  United States trademark for that brand; (3) the Department of Revenue states
  6,868,000 United brand cigarettes were sold in South Carolina in 2001; (4)
  Sumatra, either on its own or by someone else on its behalf, filed an
  ingredient report for the United brand cigarettes with the Center for Disease
  Control; (5) Sumatra admits it packaged its cigarettes in packs and cartons
  which bear the United States-required health warnings; and (6) the United brand
  packaging identifies the cigarettes as an â€œAmerican blend,â€ has a Surgeon
  Generalâ€™s warning, and shows an eagle and striped packaging.Â  Regardless of how
  the cigarettes arrived in South Carolina, minimum contacts are established by
  the above information.Â  Sumatraâ€™s actions indicate that it purposely availed
  itself of conducting business in all 50 states, including South Carolina.Â  It is
  troubling that Sumatra insists it could engage in the activities listed above but
  avoid paying into state escrow accounts and avoid suit in each and every state
  of the nation by asserting the lack of personal jurisdiction in each state.Â  We
  find Sumatra should have reasonably anticipated that it would be haled into
  court in a state such as South Carolina.[6]
 While there are
  sufficient minimum contacts such that the court has the â€œpowerâ€ to adjudicate
  the action, it must also be determined whether the exercise of jurisdiction is
  â€œreasonableâ€ or â€œfair.â€Â  Cockrell, supra.Â  Under the fairness
  prong, the court must consider:Â  (1) the duration of the activity of the
  nonresident within the state; (2) the character and circumstances of the
  commission of the nonresidentâ€™s acts; (3) the inconvenience resulting to the
  parties by conferring or refusing to confer jurisdiction over the nonresident;
  and (4) the Stateâ€™s interest in exercising jurisdiction.Â  Id.
The exercise of
  jurisdiction over Sumatra is reasonable and fair.Â  While it may be inconvenient
  for Sumatra to travel to the United States to defend the action against it, the
  Stateâ€™s interest in exercising jurisdiction outweighs any such inconvenience.Â  The
  State has a valid interest in protecting itself against any suits that arise
  from a person smoking the United brand of cigarettes.Â  Given the volume of
  those cigarettes sold within South Carolina, it is reasonable for Sumatra to be
  haled into a South Carolina court.
The State has shown
  that the court has the power to adjudicate the action and that it is reasonable
  to exercise jurisdiction. Â Therefore, the exercise of jurisdiction over Sumatra does not offend due process.Â  Accordingly, the lower court properly found it could
  exercise personal jurisdiction over Sumatra.
II. Summary judgment
Sumatra argues the court erred by granting summary judgment
  to the State and denying its cross-motion for summary judgment.
The lower court, in
  its 2006 order, found that Sumatra is a tobacco product manufacturer under the
  Escrow Fund Act.Â  The court noted that Sumatra admitted it is a manufacturer
  and that it did not contest that its cigarettes were sold in South Carolina.Â 
  The court stated that the only question was whether Sumatra intended that the
  cigarettes it manufactured be sold in the United States and that this question
  was answered by several undisputed facts:Â  (1) Sumatraâ€™s acknowledgement that
  it manufactures the United brand; (2) Sumatraâ€™s acknowledgement that its United
  States trademark for the brand may indicate an intent to sell in the United
  States; (3) the Department of Revenueâ€™s reports that almost seven million
  United brand cigarettes were sold in South Carolina in 2001; (4) Sumatraâ€™s
  packaging for United brand identifies it as an â€œAmerican blend;â€ and (5) the
  Center for Disease Controlâ€™s ingredient reporting compliance list showing that
  an ingredient list was submitted for Sumatra.Â  The court noted that these
  factors, even without the bill of lading attached to the Battah affidavit, are
  sufficient to conclude Sumatra is a â€œtobacco product manufacturerâ€ within the
  meaning of Â§ 11-47-20(i)(1).
We
  find the trial court properly granted the Stateâ€™s motion for summary judgment
  and ordered Sumatra to make payments pursuant to the Escrow Fund Act because
  the above undisputed facts cited by the trial court establish Sumatraâ€™s intent to
  sell its cigarettes in South Carolina as required by the Escrow Fund Act.[7]Â  See Rule 56(c), SCRCP (summary judgment is appropriate when â€œthe pleadings, depositions,
  answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the
  affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact
  and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of lawâ€).Â 
  Accordingly, the decisions of the lower court are
AFFIRMED.

BEATTY, J., and
  Acting Justices J. Michelle Childs and John W. Kittredge, concur. Acting
  Justice James W. Johnson, Jr., not participating.Â Â  


[1]See Â§ 11-47-20(e) (Supp. 2007).
[2]See Â§ 11-47-20(f) (Supp. 2007). 
[3]Sumatra further argues
  the Battah affidavit is inadmissible hearsay.Â  However, Sumatra does not point
  to any particular statement within the affidavit that would not be admissible
  in evidence; therefore, this argument is deemed abandoned.Â  See Colleton
  County Taxpayers Assâ€™n v. School Dist. of Colleton County, 371 S.C. 224,
  638 S.E.2d 685 (2006) (issue is deemed abandoned if the argument in the
  brief is conclusory).
[4]S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-803 has since been amended. The subsection has not been
  changed; however, the previous statute applies because the new statute is
  applicable only to causes of action arising after July 1, 2005. 
[5]Sumatra contends this
  Court should embrace the â€œstream of commerce plusâ€ theory of personal
  jurisdiction.Â  This theory arose in a plurality opinion by Justice Sandra Day
  Oâ€™Connor of the United States Supreme Court in Asahi Metal Ind. Co., Ltd. v.
  Superior Court of California, 480 U.S. 102 (1987).Â  The â€œstream of commerce
  plusâ€ theory states that the placement of a product into the stream of
  commerce, without more, is not an act of the defendant purposely directed
  toward the forum state.Â  The theory maintains that additional conduct
  indicating an intent or purpose to serve the market in the forum state is also
  necessary.Â  Asahi, 480 U.S. at 112.Â  Only three other justices signed
  onto this theory.Â  Justice William Brennan and three other justices maintained
  that simply placing a product into the stream of commerce is consistent with
  the Due Process Clause and they would not require a showing of additional
  conduct to assert jurisdiction.Â  Id. at 117.Â  We, therefore, decline to
  embrace the â€œstream of commerce plusâ€ theory.
[6]See State
  v. Grand Tobacco, 871 N.E.2d 1255 (Ohio Ct. App.), appeal not allowed, 868
  N.E.2d 680 (Ohio 2007) (finding a foreign tobacco product manufacturer has
  sufficient minimum contacts with Ohio such that the state can exercise personal
  jurisdiction over the company; noting that over 25 million units of Grand
  Tobaccoâ€™s products were sold in Ohio from 2000 to 2003; and that Grand Tobacco
  took steps within the United States to trademark its products, to comply with
  federal regulations for the sale of cigarettes by submitting ingredient lists
  to the Center for Disease Control, and to distribute its products; it had
  purposely availed itself of conducting business in all 50 states, including
  Ohio).
[7]Sumatra
  argues the Escrow Fund Act violates the takings provision of the South Carolina
  Constitution and that the Act, as applied to Sumatra, violates antitrust laws.Â 
  The trial court found that these arguments were not before the court because
  they were not raised in Sumatraâ€™s answer.Â  The court also denied the motion to
  amend the answer because Sumatra filed the motion to amend after the motion for
  summary judgment was filed and over two years after Sumatra had filed its answer.Â 
  Sumatra does not appeal the denial of the motion to amend.Â  Accordingly,
  whether the motion to amend was properly denied is not preserved for the
  Courtâ€™s review and thus the takings and price-fixing arguments are not before
  the Court.Â  See Rule 208(b)(1)(D), SCACR; Jinks v. Richland County,
  355 S.C. 341, 585 S.E.2d 281 (2003) (issue not argued in the brief is deemed
  abandoned and precludes consideration on appeal).

description: In this post-conviction relief case, we reverse the PCR judge's decision finding Petitioner's trial counsel was not ineffective in establishing Petitioner's defense of third-party guilt for the charge of armed robbery.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Bruce Randall
          Miller, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26523
  Submitted April 16, 2008 - Filed July 28,
2008Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Appellate
          Defender Robert M. Pachak, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense,
          Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Karen
          Ratigan, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  In this case, the
  post-conviction relief (PCR) court found trial counsel was not ineffective in
  establishing Bruce Randall Millerâ€™s defense of third-party guilt for the charge
  of armed robbery. Â This Court granted certiorari to review the PCR courtâ€™s
  decision.Â  Because Millerâ€™s sole defense was mistaken identity and third-party
  guilt, we conclude there is no probative evidence to support the PCR courtâ€™s
  findings of fact and conclusions of law regarding trial counselâ€™s
  effectiveness.Â  Therefore, we reverse the decision of the PCR court and grant
  Miller relief with respect to his armed robbery conviction.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Around
  9:00 a.m. on December 9, 2001, James Holden stopped by the Liâ€™l Cricket
  convenience store on White Horse Road in Greenville to use the pay phone.Â  As
  Holden was getting back into his truck, he was approached by an
  African-American male asking for directions to Interstate 85.Â  After Holden
  motioned in the direction of I-85, the man pointed a gun at him and demanded
  his wallet.Â  When the man realized that Holden did not have any money in his
  wallet, he ordered Holden to empty his pockets.Â  Holden then turned over $106
  in cash.Â  According to Holden, the man took the money and drove off in a â€œbluish
  purpleâ€ colored vehicle.Â  Holden followed the vehicle until the man pulled into
  a nearby apartment complex.Â  During the pursuit, Holden was able to take down
  the license plate number.
Holden returned to
  the convenience store and called police to report the robbery.Â  Stacy Snider, a
  deputy with the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Department, responded to the
  scene.Â  Holden described the suspect as a medium build, five-foot-ten inch, 170
  pound African-American male with a â€œFu Manchu mustache,â€ similar to a goatee.Â 
  In terms of clothing, Holden claimed the suspect was wearing a white ski hat, a
  black nylon jacket, a black shirt, dark pants, and dark tennis shoes.Â  He
  further stated the suspect was wearing â€œa necklace or a gold braid or something
  made into the shirt.â€Â  Holden also described the suspectâ€™s vehicle and gave the
  license plate number to Deputy Snider. Â Using this information, Deputy Snider
  determined that the vehicle, a Kia Sephia, was registered to Stephanie Pauling. 
On December 12,
  2001, Antonio Bailey, an investigator with the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s
  Department, continued the investigation by contacting Holden.Â  Based on
  Holdenâ€™s written statement and the vehicle registration, Investigator Bailey
  interviewed Stephanie Pauling, Millerâ€™s then girlfriend, and her aunt, Brenda
  Johnson, who lived at the address where the vehicle had been registered.Â  As a
  result of this investigation, Investigator Bailey compiled a photographic
  lineup and presented it to Holden on December 18, 2001.Â  At that time, Holden
  selected Millerâ€™s photograph and positively identified him as the man who had
  robbed him.Â  The next day, Investigator Bailey arrested Miller.Â  The Greenville County jail intake form listed Miller as five-feet-eight inches tall and
  weighing 130 pounds.Â  Â 
After a Greenville County grand jury indicted him, Miller was tried for armed robbery.Â  In addition
  to Holden and the investigating officers, the State presented Stephanie Pauling
  as its primary witness to establish that Miller had access to her vehicle at
  the time of the armed robbery.Â  Pauling testified she began dating Miller in
  September 2001 and eventually moved in with him.Â  She claimed that Miller often
  borrowed her car and that he drove off in the vehicle on December 2, 2001.Â 
  According to Pauling, she did not see Miller until one week later.Â  At that
  time, Miller told her that she could find her car on Poinsette Highway where he
  had left it.Â  Because Miller claimed he had lost her car keys, Pauling arranged
  to meet with her aunt, Brenda Johnson, who gave her the spare set of car keys
  in order that she could retrieve the car. Â When questioned about the specifics
  of the armed robbery, Pauling testified that Miller owned a handgun and that Miller
  was wearing a gold medallion on the day of the robbery. 
On
  cross-examination, Millerâ€™s trial counsel brought out that Pauling was
  currently charged with three armed robberies in Greenville.Â  With respect to
  one of these robberies, Pauling admitted that she initially implicated Miller,
  but ultimately changed her statement and identified Derrick Miller, Bruce Millerâ€™s
  nephew, as a participant.Â  During this portion of cross-examination, the State
  objected as trial counsel began to question Pauling about Derrick Miller and
  his involvement in the robberies.Â  Outside the presence of the jury, trial counsel
  inquired whether he would be permitted to question Pauling regarding the
  specifics of her three armed robbery charges in an attempt to establish that Derrick
  Miller, not Bruce Miller, was the person who robbed Holden.Â  The trial judge
  sustained the Stateâ€™s objection and trial counsel concluded his
  cross-examination of Pauling.Â  
Following
  the bench conference, trial counsel proffered his cross-examination of
  Pauling.Â  During the proffer, Pauling testified that Derrick Miller was a
  co-defendant in all three armed robberies with which she had been charged.Â  She
  also described Derrick Miller as an African-American male, who was
  approximately five-feet-seven inches tall, weighed 170 pounds, and had facial
  hair over his lip and under his chin.Â  At the conclusion of the proffer, trial
  counsel contended this testimony was relevant as evidence of third-party
  guilt.Â  Specifically, he stated that he wanted to establish before the jury
  that another individual with similar physical characteristics to Bruce Miller
  had access to Paulingâ€™s vehicle and had been involved in recent armed robberies
  in Greenville using the same vehicle during the same time period.Â  The trial
  judge then permitted trial counsel to recall Pauling and question her again
  outside the presence of the jury.Â  During this second proffer, Pauling
  acknowledged that her car was used during each of the three robberies for which
  she and Derrick Miller were charged as well as the one for which Bruce Miller
  was charged.
After denying
  Millerâ€™s motion for a directed verdict and a brief recess, the trial judge
  returned to the courtroom and informed the attorneys that he had reversed his earlier
  ruling.Â  The judge stated that he would permit Millerâ€™s counsel to question
  Pauling regarding Derrick Millerâ€™s physical characteristics and that Pauling
  would be â€œtestifying consistent with the proffer.â€
During
  her cross-examination before the jury, Pauling described Derrick Miller as an
  African-American male who was approximately five-feet-seven inches tall and
  weighed 170 pounds.Â  She also acknowledged that he has a â€œFu Manchu mustache.â€ Â In
  reply, the State recalled Holden as a witness who again positively identified Bruce
  Miller as the man who robbed him. 
Miller did not
  testify or present any witnesses on his behalf.Â  After the jury convicted him
  of armed robbery, the trial judge sentenced him to eighteen years imprisonment.Â  
Miller appealed
  his conviction to the Court of Appeals.Â  After the Court of Appeals affirmed
  his conviction,[1] Miller filed an application for post-conviction relief.Â  The State filed a
  return and requested an evidentiary hearing.Â  
At the hearing,
  Millerâ€™s PCR counsel called Bruce Miller and trial counsel as witnesses.Â  Miller
  maintained that his nephew, Derrick Miller, committed the armed robbery for
  which he was charged.Â  Miller claimed his trial counsel was ineffective in that
  he failed to:Â  (1) obtain an expert witness on eyewitness identification
  testimony; and (2) adequately present the third-party guilt of his nephew, Derrick
  Miller.Â  In terms of third-party guilt, Miller believed that trial counsel
  should have established that his nephew had similar physical features and had
  been charged with three armed robberies in Greenville that occurred around the
  time Holden was robbed.Â  Additionally, Miller claimed that Derrick used
  Paulingâ€™s vehicle and owned a handgun similar to the one that Holden claimed to
  have seen during the robbery. 
Trial counsel
  admitted that he erred in failing to bring out through Paulingâ€™s
  cross-examination that her car was used and a similar handgun was used in the
  robbery of Holden as well as the other three armed robberies for which she and Derrick
  Miller were charged.Â  Because Millerâ€™s sole defense was misidentification and
  third-party guilt, trial counsel conceded that he â€œmissed [his] opportunityâ€
  during Paulingâ€™s testimony to specifically tie in the gun and vehicle used in
  all of the robberies.Â  By means of explanation, trial counsel stated he was
  remiss in not connecting the handgun and Paulingâ€™s vehicle because he was
  caught off guard when the trial judge reversed his initial ruling.Â  
At the conclusion
  of the hearing, the PCR court denied Millerâ€™s application for post-conviction
  relief.Â  Although he acknowledged that it was a â€œclose case,â€ the court found
  Miller did not meet his burden of proof to warrant relief.Â  In a written order,
  the PCR court affirmed his oral ruling and dismissed Millerâ€™s application.Â 
  Specifically, the court held that Miller did not meet his burden of
  establishing error or prejudice regarding how trial counsel failed to
  effectively handle the following issues:Â  (1) eyewitness identification; and
  (2) third-party guilt.Â  In terms of third-party guilt, the court found that
  â€œtrial counsel was allowed to present a third party guilt defense at trial.Â 
  This Court finds that trial counselâ€™s hindsight admission regarding his failure
  to ask Pauling (during the second cross-examination) about the similar car and
  gun does [not] operate to satisfy the Applicantâ€™s burden of proving error.â€
This Court granted
  Millerâ€™s petition for certiorari to review the PCR courtâ€™s denial of his application
  for post-conviction relief.
DISCUSSION
Miller
  asserts the PCR court erred in failing to find trial counsel was ineffective in
  not cross-examining Stephanie Pauling regarding similar armed robberies
  allegedly committed by Derrick Miller.Â  Because his entire defense rested on
  mistaken identity and third-party guilt,[2] Miller contends his counselâ€™s ineffectiveness was prejudicial and
  warranted a reversal of his conviction.Â  We agree.
A
  defendant has the right to the effective assistance of counsel under the Sixth
  Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).Â  â€œThere is a strong presumption that counsel rendered adequate
  assistance and exercised reasonable professional judgment in making all
  significant decisions in the case.â€Â  Ard v. Catoe, 372 S.C. 318, 331,
  642 S.E.2d 590, 596 (2007), cert. denied, 128 S. Ct. 370 (2007).Â Â  
In a
  PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he is
  entitled to relief.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d
  514, 517 (2000).Â  In order to prove that counsel was ineffective, the PCR
  applicant must show that: (1) counselâ€™s performance was deficient; and (2)
  there is a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s errors, the result of
  the trial would have been different.Â  Id. (citing Strickland v.
    Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984)).Â  â€œA reasonable probability is a
  probability sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcome of the trial.â€Â  Ard,
  372 S.C. at 331, 642 S.E.2d at 596. â€œFurthermore, when a defendantâ€™s conviction
  is challenged, â€˜the question is whether there is a reasonable probability that,
  absent the errors, the fact finder would have had a reasonable doubt respecting
  guilt.â€™â€ Id. (quoting Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 695 (1984)).
â€œThis
  Court gives great deference to the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s
  findings of fact and conclusions of law.â€Â  Dempsey v. State, 363 S.C.
  365, 368, 610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005).Â  We will uphold the findings of the PCR court when there is
  any evidence of probative value to support them. Â Suber v. State, 371
  S.C. 554, 558-59, 640 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2007). Â However, this Court will
  reverse if there is no probative evidence to support the PCR courtâ€™s findings or the decision is controlled by an
  error of law. Â Id.; Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 145, 526
  S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000).
Although
  we are cognizant of our deferential standard of review, we find there is no
  probative evidence to support the PCR courtâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of
  law regarding trial counselâ€™s effectiveness.Â  We believe the record established
  that trial counselâ€™s performance was deficient and that, but for counselâ€™s
  error, there was a reasonable probability that the result of Millerâ€™s trial would
  have been different.Â  Â  
The
  State established the charge of armed robbery against Bruce Miller based on a
  single eyewitness.Â  Both trial counsel and Miller maintained that the defense
  theory was misidentification and third-party guilt.Â  In terms of
  misidentification, trial counsel failed to call an expert witness to testify
  regarding eyewitness identification testimony.Â  Thus, the key defense was
  third-party guilt.Â  
In
  view of this limited defense, it was crucial for trial counsel to elicit
  testimony from Pauling that showed the similarities between the armed robberies
  for which she and Derrick Miller were charged and the one for which Bruce Miller
  was charged.Â  Based on the proffer of Paulingâ€™s testimony and the transcript
  from the PCR hearing, it is clear that trial counsel could have established Derrick
  Millerâ€™s third-party guilt by showing that Paulingâ€™s vehicle was used as the
  â€œget awayâ€ car in each of the robberies and that a similar handgun was used.Â  Â 
Although
  trial counsel, through Paulingâ€™s testimony, was able to establish a physical description
  of Derrick Miller, this was not sufficient to adequately establish a defense of
  third-party guilt.Â  A review of Holdenâ€™s testimony reveals that he described
  the robber as an African-American male who was approximately five-feet-ten
  inches tall and weighed 170 pounds.Â  He also described the robberâ€™s facial hair
  as a â€œFu Manchu mustacheâ€ or â€œgoatee.â€Â  Significantly, this description is akin
  to Derrick Millerâ€™s physical features rather than Bruce Millerâ€™s. Â Additionally,
  Paulingâ€™s credibility was questionable at best given she initially implicated Bruce
  Miller in one of the other three armed robberies until she became aware that he
  could not have been involved because he was in jail at the time of the crime.Â 
  Inferentially, Pauling could have been â€œcoveringâ€ for Derrick Miller for
  Holdenâ€™s armed robbery as she did when she falsely identified Bruce Miller in
  another robbery.Â  
Furthermore,
  trial counsel conceded he was remiss in failing to adequately cross-examine
  Pauling regarding the specifics of the other armed robberies. Counsel attempted
  to elicit specific testimony of third-party guilt during the proffer of
  Paulingâ€™s testimony; however, he failed to do so in front of the jury when
  given an opportunity by the trial judge to question her further regarding the
  use of her car and a similar gun during the charged robberies.
Based
  on the foregoing, we conclude the record is devoid of any probative evidence to
  support the PCR courtâ€™s decision to dismiss Millerâ€™s application.Â  Clearly,
  both the trial judge and the PCR court recognized there was evidence of
  third-party guilt.Â  Specifically, the trial judge gave trial counsel the
  opportunity to establish this defense before the jury.Â  Moreover, the PCR court
  found that â€œtrial counsel clearly pursued the defense of third-party guilt at
  trial.â€ Â Yet, the evidence established that counsel was deficient in adequately
  cross-examining Pauling regarding the specifics of the other three armed
  robberies for which she and Derrick Miller were charged as well as pointing out
  that Derrick Millerâ€™s physical features were similar to the robber as described
  by Holden.Â  Because Millerâ€™s sole defense was mistaken identity and third-party
  guilt, he was prejudiced by trial counselâ€™s error and entitled to
  post-conviction relief.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we reverse the PCR courtâ€™s decision and
  grant relief as to Millerâ€™s armed robbery conviction.

REVERSED.Â 
  Â 
MOORE and WALLER, JJ.,
  concur. TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which PLEICONES, J.,
  concurs. PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which TOAL, C.J.,
  concurs.

CHIEF
  JUSTICE TOAL:Â  I join in Justice
  Pleiconesâ€™ dissent.Â  In my opinion, this evidence does not meet the threshold
  for third-party guilt.Â  
In
  my view, testimony that Pauling and Derrick Miller committed other robberies
  using Paulingâ€™s vehicle and that a similar gun was used in all four robberies
  is not evidence that is inconsistent with Petitionerâ€™s guilt.Â  State v. Beckham, 334 S.C. 302, 317, 513 S.E.2d 606, 614 (1999) (recognizing that third-party guilt evidence is limited to facts
  which are inconsistent with the defendantâ€™s guilt).Â 
  Furthermore, I agree with Justice Pleicones that Petitioner failed to show he
  was prejudiced by trial counselâ€™s alleged failure to adequately present this
  evidence.Â  The jury heard testimony from Pauling that she pled guilty to an
  armed robbery that she committed with Derrick Miller in which she drove the
  â€œget-awayâ€ vehicle.Â  
Furthermore,
  in my view, Petitioner failed to show trial counsel was ineffective in failing
  to call an expert on witness identification.Â  Petitioner did not offer any such
  expert at his PCR hearing, and thus, he failed to meet his burden of proving
  prejudice.Â  See Lorenzen v. State, 376
  S.C. 521, 530, 657 S.E.2d 771, 776-77 (2008) (holding that the
  PCR applicant failed to show he was prejudiced by trial counselâ€™s failure to
  call an eyewitness identification expert because â€œit is merely speculative that
  these allegedly favorable expert witnesses would have aided in
  his defense.â€).Â  
For
  these reasons, I believe there is evidence to support the PCR courtâ€™s findings,
  and I would affirm the order denying Petitioner relief.
PLEICONES,
J., concurs.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent and would affirm the
  post-conviction relief (PCR) judgeâ€™s finding that petitionerâ€™s trial counsel
  was not ineffective in failing to adequately present evidence of third-party guilt.Â  E.g., Ard v. Catoe, 372 S.C. 318, 642 S.E.2d 590 (2007) (PCR
  findings must be upheld where supported by any evidence of probative value in
  the record).
Under South Carolinaâ€™s third-party guilt evidence rule:

  Evidence
    offered by accused as to the commission of the crime by another person must be
    limited to such facts as are inconsistent with his own guilt, and to such facts
    as raise a reasonable inference or presumption as to his own innocence;
    evidence which can have (no) other effect that than to cast a bare suspicion
    upon another, or to raise a conjectural inference as to the commission of the
    crime by another, is not admissibleâ€¦.Â  [B]efore such testimony can be received,
    there must be such proof of connection with it, such a train of facts or circumstances,
    as tends clearly to point out such other person as the guilty party.Â  State
      v. Gregory, 198 S.C. 98 at 104-105, 16 S.E.2d 532 at 534-535 (1941)
    (quoting 16 C.J., Criminal Law Â§ 1085, p. 560 (1918) and 20 Am.Jur., Evidence Â§
    265, p. 254 (1939); footnotes omitted).
  Cited
    in Holmes v. South Carolina, 547 U.S. 319, 328 (2006).[3]

At the outset, I must express
  reservations whether the third-party guilt evidence proffered by petitioner at
  trial met the threshold for admissibility.Â  In my view, Stephanie Paulingâ€™s
  testimony did little more than raise a conjectural inference that Derrick
  Miller, rather than petitioner, may have robbed James Holder.Â  State v.
    Gregory, supra.
In any case, there
  is evidence in the record to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that trial counsel
  was not deficient in casting suspicion on Derrick through his cross-examination
  of Pauling.Â  The majority points to two facts which trial counsel failed to
  elicit to find trial counsel ineffective: 1) that Paulingâ€™s car was used in her
  and Derrickâ€™s armed robberies and 2) that a similar gun was used in all four
  robberies.Â  In my view, trial counselâ€™s failure to cross-examine Pauling about
  these two â€œsimilaritiesâ€ was not deficient nor was petitioner prejudiced
  thereby.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 460 U.S. 668 (1984) (defendant
  alleging trial counsel was ineffective must establish both deficient
  performance and resulting prejudice).
It appears that
  Pauling testified for the State in petitionerâ€™s trial as part of an
  understanding that, following her testimony, she was to be permitted to plead
  down her three armed robbery charges to three counts of accessory after the
  fact.Â  In those three cases, Pauling was alleged to have been the getaway car
  driver while two codefendants (one Derrick) robbed or attempted to rob
  convenience stores and a fast food restaurant.Â  While Pauling did not
  explicitly testify that she was driving her car during these three crimes,
  there was no suggestion that she was driving any other vehicle.[4]Â 
  The testimony focused on only this automobile, as did the attorneysâ€™ closing
  arguments.Â  In my opinion, trial counselâ€™s failure to specifically question
  Pauling about the car used in the armed robberies in which she was the getaway
  driver was not deficient, nor was petitioner prejudiced by this omission since
  it was clear to the jury that the same car was involved in all four incidents.Â  Strickland v. Washington, supra.
The majority also
  holds trial counselâ€™s failure to exploit the similarities between the gun used
  to rob Holder and the gun used in the three other armed robberies was
  ineffective.Â  During her in camera trial testimony, however, Pauling
  stated that the gun used in the robberies in which she participated â€œdidnâ€™t
  look like the other one.â€Â  In my opinion, counsel cannot be deemed ineffective
  for failing to present evidence at trial through Pauling of the gunsâ€™
  similarities.
Having concluded
  that there is evidence of probative value in the record which supports the
  findings of the PCR judge, I would affirm the order denying petitioner a new
  trial.Â  Ard v. Catoe, supra.
TOAL, C.J.,
  concurs.


[1]Â Â  State v. Miller, Op. No. 2004-UP-620 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Dec. 13, 2004).
[2]Â Â  In terms of third-party guilt, this
  Court has imposed strict limitations on its admissibility. Â State
    v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 81, 538 S.E.2d 257, 265 (Ct. App. 2000).Â 
  â€œEvidence offered by a defendant as to the commission of the crime by another
  person is limited to facts which are inconsistent with the defendantâ€™s guilt.â€ Id.Â  â€œThe evidence must raise a reasonable inference as to the accusedâ€™s
  innocence.â€Â  Id.Â  Recently, after Millerâ€™s
  trial, our United States Supreme Court clarified the above-outlined rule
  regarding the admission of third-party guilt in Holmes v. South Carolina,
  547 U.S. 319 (2006).Â  Holmes essentially permits a defendant to
  introduce evidence of third-party guilt regardless of the strength of the
  Stateâ€™s case if the evidence offered by the accused as to the commission of the
  crime by another person is limited to such facts as are inconsistent with his
  own guilt and that raise a reasonable inference or presumption as to his own
  innocence.Â  Holmes, 547 U.S. at 328-29.
[3] In Holmes, the United State Supreme Court
  found unconstitutional a variant of South Carolinaâ€™s third-party guilt rule
  which permitted strong evidence of guilt (especially forensic) to trump the
defendantâ€™s right to present third-party guilt evidence.
[4] This is especially so in light of Paulingâ€™s
  testimony that only she, her aunt, and petitioner were permitted to drive the
  car, and evidence that her participation in the three robberies was motivated,
  at least in part, by the fact she had just lost her job and was unable to make
her car payments.

PER CURIAM:Â Â 
  In this judicial disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary
  Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant
  to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct
  and consents to a public reprimand.Â  Respondent has also resigned his position
  and has agreed never to seek nor accept a judicial office in South Carolina
  without the express written permission of this Court after written notice to
  ODC.Â  We accept the agreement and publicly reprimand respondent, the most
severe sanction we are able to impose under these circumstances.

Facts
Respondent admits in the Agreement for Discipline by Consent that
  he made inappropriate statements in commenting on a warrant.Â  Specifically,
  respondent referred to the use of crack cocaine and addiction thereto as a
  â€œblack manâ€™s disease.â€Â  On another occasion, respondent reacted in an overly
  harsh manner to comments made by a speaker at a seminar on criminal domestic
  violence.
Respondent also admits that during a bond hearing, he directed a
  defendant in a criminal domestic violence case to look at the victim, which was
  contrary to instructions given to the defendant by the transportation officer
  from the detention center.Â  While conducting bond court on another occasion,
  respondent incorrectly advised a defendant of the penalty for the charge
  against the defendant.
Finally, respondent admits engaging in behavior that, while
  unintentional, could reasonably have been viewed as inappropriate by female
  employees.
Law
By his conduct, respondent has violated the following provisions
  of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR: Canon 1 (a judge shall
  observe high standards of conduct so that the integrity and independence of the
  judiciary is preserved); Canon 1A (a judge should participate in establishing, maintaining and
    enforcing high standards of conduct, and shall personally observe those
    standards so that the integrity and independence of the judiciary will be
    preserved); Canon 2 (a judge shall avoid impropriety and the appearance of
    impropriety in all of the judgeâ€™s activities); Canon 2(A)(a judge shall avoid impropriety
  and the appearance of impropriety by acting at all times in a manner that
  promotes public confidence in the integrity of the judiciary); and Canon 3B (a judge shall be patient, dignified
    and courteous to litigants, jurors, witnesses, lawyers and others with whom the
    judge deals in an official capacity).Â  Respondent has also violated the following provisions of
  the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR: Rule
  7(a)(1)(it shall be a ground for discipline for a judge to violate the Code of
  Judicial Conduct); Rule 7(a)(4)(it shall be a ground for discipline for a judge
  to persistently perform judicial duties in an incompetent
  or neglectful manner); and
  Rule 7(a)(9)(it shall be a ground for discipline for a judge to violate
  the Judgeâ€™s Oath of Office contained in Rule 502.1, SCACR).
Conclusion
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and issue a
  public reprimand because respondent is no longer a magistrate and because he
  has agreed not to hereafter seek nor accept another judicial position in South Carolina without first obtaining permission from this Court.[1]Â  As previously noted, this is the
  strongest punishment we can give respondent, given the fact that he has already
  resigned his duties as a magistrate.Â  See In re Gravely, 321 S.C.
  235, 467 S.E.2d 924 (1996)(â€œA public reprimand is the most severe sanction that
  can be imposed when the respondent no longer holds judicial office.â€)Â 
  Accordingly, respondent is hereby publicly reprimanded for his conduct.
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1] Respondent has agreed that, in the event he does
  seek such permission from this Court, he shall not do so without prior written
  notice to ODC and without allowing ODC to disclose to this Court information relevant
  to these proceedings and any information relevant to the issue of respondent
holding judicial office.
