THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Freddie Vernell
          Lomax, Petitioner,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26525
  Submitted June 26, 2008 - Filed July 28,
2008Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Appellate
          Defender LaNelle C. DuRant, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense,
          Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Karen
          Ratigan, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  In this post-conviction
  relief case, the Court granted certiorari to review the PCR judgeâ€™s denial of
  relief for Freddie Vernell Lomaxâ€™s plea of guilty to multiple drug offenses. Â Â In
  her petition, Lomaxâ€™s (Petitionerâ€™s) sole contention is that the PCR judge
  erred in failing to find a conflict of interest existed when her plea counsel
  simultaneously represented both Petitioner and her husband during guilty pleas
  which arose out of related offenses.Â  We reverse the decision of the PCR judge.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On
  August 20, 1997, Petitioner distributed crack cocaine to an undercover officer
  near a public park in Greenville. Â Based on this transaction, officers with the
  Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Department served Petitioner with two arrest
  warrants for the charges of distribution of crack cocaine and distribution of
  crack cocaine within a half mile of a public park.Â  The officers proceeded to
  serve the warrants after they observed Petitioner drive away from her home.Â 
  After they stopped Petitioner, the officers arrested her and searched her
  vehicle.Â  This search revealed .58 grams of cocaine and 64.79 grams of crack
  cocaine.
As a result of the
  vehicle search, the officers sought to procure a search warrant for Petitionerâ€™s
  home.Â  While waiting for the search warrant, the officers conducted
  surveillance of Petitionerâ€™s home.Â  Shortly after their arrival, the officers
  observed Noah Lomax, Petitionerâ€™s husband (Husband), drive away from the
  residence.Â  The officers stopped him a short distance from the residence.Â  At
  that time, he consented to a search of his vehicle.Â  During their search, the
  officers found 22.47 grams of cocaine, 178.11 grams of crack cocaine, $17,000
  in cash, as well as seventeen clear plastic bags.
Subsequently, Husband
  gave a statement to the officers that he knew his wife was being arrested and
  he went to their home to remove the drugs and money.Â  As a result of their
  investigation, the officers executed a search warrant for the coupleâ€™s home.Â 
  During the search, the officers discovered quantities of marijuana, crack
  cocaine, and a mixture of both drugs.Â  Additionally, they discovered $1,369 in
  cash. 
Petitioner was
  released from jail after serving nineteen days.Â  Less than a month after her
  release, Petitioner distributed crack cocaine to undercover officers on three
  separate occasions.Â  
Based on Petitionerâ€™s
  conduct, a Greenville County grand jury indicted Petitioner for the following
  offenses:Â  four counts of distribution of crack cocaine; distribution of crack
  cocaine within a half mile of a school or public park; trafficking in crack cocaine
  in excess of 200 grams, which was later amended to an amount between 28 and 100
  grams; possession with intent to distribute cocaine within proximity of a
  school; trafficking in cocaine; possession with intent to distribute crack
  cocaine within proximity of a school; possession with intent to distribute
  marijuana; and possession with intent to distribute marijuana within proximity
  of a school.Â  
Subsequently,
  Petitioner and Husband, both represented by the same attorney, simultaneously
  pled guilty.Â  The solicitor explained to
  the plea judge that the State intended to present both pleas jointly given the
  defendants were husband and wife and the facts giving rise to their charges
  were the same.Â  After engaging in a plea colloquy with Petitioner and Husband
  individually, the plea judge accepted their guilty pleas as freely and
  voluntarily given and issued his respective sentences.Â  
Husband
  pled guilty to possession of marijuana with intent to distribute within
  proximity of a school and was sentenced to three yearsâ€™ imprisonment. Â The judge
  sentenced Petitioner to concurrent terms of ten years on each count of
  distribution of crack cocaine, ten years for distribution of crack cocaine
  within proximity of a school, twenty-five years for trafficking in crack
  cocaine, ten years for trafficking in cocaine, ten years for PWID crack cocaine
  within proximity of a school, ten years for PWID cocaine within proximity of a
  school, five years for PWID marijuana, and ten years for PWID marijuana within
  proximity of a school.
Petitioner did not
  appeal her guilty plea or sentences.Â  On November 20, 1998, Petitioner filed an
  application for post-conviction relief.Â  The State filed a Return and requested
  an evidentiary hearing. 
On
  December 14, 2006, the PCR court held a hearing on petitionerâ€™s application.[1]Â  At the PCR hearing, Petitionerâ€™s PCR
  counsel called Petitioner and her plea counsel as witnesses.Â  Petitioner
  contended she was hurt by plea counselâ€™s representation of both her and Husband
  at the plea proceeding.Â  Petitioner believed that plea counselâ€™s argument for
  leniency on behalf of Husband was detrimental to her given that counsel
  compared her involvement in the crimes to that of Husband.Â  Petitioner also
  claimed she was prejudiced by plea counselâ€™s dual representation because plea
  counsel â€œlingeredâ€ more on Husbandâ€™s case.Â  Petitioner asserted that plea
  counsel should have focused more on her case because she had confessed to the
  crimes and was subject to a more severe sentence.Â  
Additionally,
  Petitioner testified she was informed that she would be tried separately and
  did not recall ever being asked whether she wanted to waive any conflict of
  interest and proceed jointly with Husband.Â  Petitioner further stated that had
  she known the sentence that she would receive by pleading guilty, she would
  have requested a jury trial. 
On
  cross-examination, Petitioner acknowledged that when she hired plea counsel to
  represent her for a bond reduction she was aware that counsel was already
  representing Husband.Â  Petitioner further admitted that she agreed to have plea
  counsel represent both her and Husband on the indicted offenses. 
Plea
  counsel acknowledged she represented Petitioner and Husband on charges that
  stemmed from the same incident.Â  Although plea counsel could not remember
  whether she discussed the conflict of interest issue with Petitioner, she
  remembered specifically talking to Husband about it.Â  Counsel also stated
  neither Petitioner nor Husband voiced any objection to the dual representation,
  but instead, indicated they wanted her to represent them together.
On
  cross-examination, plea counsel stated her standard practice was to have
  clients sign a release or a waiver of a conflict of interest.Â  However, she
  could not specifically recall whether Petitioner or Husband had signed such a
  document.Â  Even if this document had been signed by Petitioner and Husband,
  plea counsel testified she could not produce it given she had shredded the case
  file years earlier. 
At
  the conclusion of plea counselâ€™s testimony, the PCR judge inquired whether
  counsel had favored one client over the other.Â  In response, plea counsel
  stated:

  No.Â  I
    did spend a lot more time with [Husband] in the beginning because he wasâ€”I mean,
    this guy had had the same job for so many years.Â  He was very close to
    retirement and they had fired him.Â  So we didâ€”I spent a lot of time with him
    seeing if there was anything we could do to get his job back. 
  As far a
    favoring one over the other, I certainly did not do that.Â  I knew that
    Petitioner was in more trouble.Â  I was hoping to get [Husband] extricated from
    the thing altogether.Â  But, I mean, he did give a statement saying that he knew
    the stuff was there and he had gone to the house to remove it.Â  And I did, on
    the record, ask that his sentence be reconsidered.Â  I donâ€™t know if I,
    actually, filed it.Â  But, I did ask [the plea judge] to reconsider
    [Petitionerâ€™s] sentence.[2]Â  

At
  the conclusion of the hearing, the PCR judge denied Petitionerâ€™s application.Â  In
  reaching this decision, the PCR judge found Petitioner was not prejudiced by
  plea counselâ€™s dual representation because there was â€œno actual conflict of
  interest in the matter.â€Â  In his written order, the PCR judge affirmed his oral
  ruling and explained his decision. Â The PCR judge prefaced his analysis with a
  finding that plea counselâ€™s testimony was credible whereas Petitionerâ€™s
  testimony was not credible.Â  The PCR judge went on to conclude that Petitioner
  failed to meet her burden of proof that plea counsel was ineffective.Â  In
  reaching this conclusion, the judge found Petitioner:Â  admitted her guilt at
  the plea proceeding; acknowledged the facts presented by the solicitor;
  communicated that she understood the rights she was waiving by pleading guilty;
  was satisfied with plea counselâ€™s representation; and had not been coerced in
  any way to plead guilty.Â  Additionally, the PCR judge specifically held that
  there was no actual conflict of interest with plea counselâ€™s dual
  representation of Petitioner and Husband. 
This
  Court granted certiorari to review the PCR judgeâ€™s denial of Petitionerâ€™s
  application for post-conviction relief.
DISCUSSION
Petitioner
  argues the PCR judge erred in failing to find that a conflict of interest
  existed when her plea counsel simultaneously represented both Petitioner and Husband
  during guilty pleas which arose out of related offenses.Â  We agree.
A
  defendant has the right to the effective assistance of counsel under the Sixth
  Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).Â  â€œThere is a strong presumption that counsel rendered
  adequate assistance and exercised reasonable professional judgment in making
  all significant decisions in the case.â€Â  Ard v. Catoe, 372 S.C. 318,
  331, 642 S.E.2d 590, 596 (2007), cert. denied, 128 S. Ct. 370 (2007).Â Â  
In a
  PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he or she is
  entitled to relief.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d
  514, 517 (2000).Â  â€œIn
  the context of a challenge to a guilty
  plea, a PCR applicant must establish both that his plea counselâ€™s
  representation was deficient and that there is a reasonable probability that
  but for counselâ€™s deficient representation, the applicant would not have pled
  guilty.â€Â  James v. State, 377 S.C. 81, 83-84, 659 S.E.2d 148, 149 (2008).Â  â€œIn determining guilty
  plea issues, it is proper to consider the guilty plea transcript as well as
  evidence at the PCR hearing.â€ Suber v. State, 371
  S.C. 554, 558, 640 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2007).
â€œThis
  Court gives great deference to the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s
  findings of fact and conclusions of law.â€Â  Dempsey v. State, 363 S.C.
  365, 368, 610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005).Â  In reviewing the PCR courtâ€™s decision, an appellate court is concerned
  only with whether any evidence of probative value exists to support that
  decision.  Smith v. State, 369 S.C. 135, 138, 631 S.E.2d 260, 261
  (2006).Â  This Court will uphold the findings of the PCR court when there is any
  evidence of probative value to support them, and will reverse the decision of
  the PCR court when it is controlled by an error of law.  Suber,
  371 S.C. at 558-59, 640 S.E.2d at 886.
â€œThe Sixth
  Amendment right to counsel attaches upon initiation of adversarial judicial
  proceedings and at all critical stages of a criminal trial.â€Â  State v. Sterling, 377 S.C. 475, 479, 661 S.E.2d 99, 101 (2008).Â  â€œTo establish a violation of the Sixth Amendment right to
  effective counsel due to a conflict of interest arising from multiple representation,
  a defendant who did not object at trial must show an actual conflict of
  interest adversely affected his attorneyâ€™s performance.â€Â  Thomas v. State,
  346 S.C. 140, 143, 551 S.E.2d 254, 256 (2001).Â  â€œAn actual conflict of interest
  occurs where an attorney owes a duty to a party whose interests are adverse to
  the defendantâ€™s.â€ Staggs v. State, 372 S.C. 549, 551, 643 S.E.2d 690,
  692 (2007).Â  This Court has further stated that an actual conflict of interest
  occurs:

  when a defense attorney places himself in a situation inherently
    conducive to divided loyalties . . . . If a defense attorney owes duties to a
    party whose interests are adverse to those of the defendant, then an actual
    conflict exists.Â  The interests of the other client and the defendant are sufficiently
    adverse if it is shown that the attorney owes a duty to the defendant to take
    some action that could be detrimental to his other client.

Duncan v. State, 281 S.C. 435, 438, 315 S.E.2d 809, 811
  (1984) (quoting Zuck v. State of Alabama, 588 F.2d 436, 439 (5th Cir.
  1979)).
â€œThe mere possibility defense counsel may have a conflict of
  interest is insufficient to impugn a criminal conviction.â€ Â State v. Gregory,
  364 S.C. 150, 152-53, 612 S.E.2d 449, 450 (2005). Â Additionally, the fact that
  counsel does not advise a defendant of the potential conflict of interest does
  not affect the constitutionality of the conviction.Â  Jackson v. State,
  329 S.C. 345, 355, 495 S.E.2d 768, 773 (1998).Â  Moreover, the â€œRules of
  Professional Conduct have no bearing on the constitutionality of a criminal
  conviction.â€Â  Langford v. State, 310 S.C. 357, 360, 426 S.E.2d 793, 795
  (1993).
â€œHowever, a defendant need not demonstrate prejudice if there is
  an actual conflict of interest.â€Â  Gregory, 364 S.C. at 153, 612 S.E.2d
  at 450.Â  â€œâ€˜But until a defendant shows that his counsel actively represented
  conflicting interests, he has not established the constitutional predicate for
  his claim of ineffective assistance.â€™â€Â  Duncan, 281 S.C. at 438, 315
  S.E.2d at 811 (quoting Cuyler v. Sullivan, 446 U.S. 335, 350 (1980)).
Applying the above-outlined analytical framework to the facts of
  the instant case, we find the PCR judge erred in denying Petitionerâ€™s
  application for post-conviction relief. Â As will be discussed, we hold the
  PCR judge erred in failing to find that an actual conflict of interest existed,
  thus rendering plea counselâ€™s representation ineffective.Â  
At the PCR hearing, both plea counsel and Petitioner testified
  that counsel spent more time preparing Husbandâ€™s case despite the fact that
  Petitioner was pleading guilty to a majority of the charged offenses and faced
  a more severe sentence.Â  
In terms of the conflict of interest, plea counsel acknowledged
  that she discussed this issue with Husband, but could not recall specifically
  talking to Petitioner about such a conflict.Â  Plea counsel also admitted that
  she argued for leniency in Husbandâ€™s case and requested the plea judge
  reconsider his sentence.Â  In contrast, plea counsel did not make these
  arguments on behalf of Petitioner.Â  Moreover, Petitionerâ€™s and Husbandâ€™s
  interests were adverse to one another given Petitioner pleaded guilty to the
  majority of the drug charges whereas Husband pleaded guilty to a single charge
  of PWID marijuana within proximity of a school.Â  Significantly, plea counsel
  stated at the plea proceeding that Husband was originally â€œcharged with
  everything,â€ but she â€œwas able to get the solicitor who had the case at the
  time to dismiss all of his cases.â€Â  A review of the plea proceeding also
  reveals that plea counsel argued for leniency on behalf of Husband by comparing
  his more limited involvement in the crimes to that of Petitioner.Â  We believe
  plea counselâ€™s approach essentially pitted Husband against Petitioner, which
  was clearly detrimental to Petitionerâ€™s interests.
In light of the foregoing, we find Petitioner established that an
  actual conflict of interest adversely affected her plea counselâ€™s performance.Â  See Thomas v. State, 346 S.C. 140, 143-45, 551 S.E.2d 254, 256
  (2001) (holding Petitioner in PCR proceeding demonstrated actual conflict of
  interest that affected her counselâ€™s performance given counsel jointly
  represented Petitioner and her husband in a case where solicitor offered a plea
  bargain that would allow the charge against one spouse to be dismissed if the
  other spouse would plead guilty to the entire amount of cocaine); see also Staggs v. State, 372 S.C. 549, 551-52, 643 S.E.2d 690, 691-92 (2007) (Petitioner
  in PCR proceeding demonstrated actual conflict of interest that adversely
  affected counselâ€™s trial performance where his counsel, who represented him on
  the charge of murder, also simultaneously represented Petitionerâ€™s father,
  mother, and brother on related accessory after the fact of murder charges); see
    generally Allan L. Schwartz, Circumstances Giving Rise to Conflict of
      Interest Between or Among Criminal Codefendants Precluding Representation by
      Same Counsel, 34 A.L.R.3d 470 (1970 & Supp. 2008) (outlining cases
  which consider what particular circumstances give rise to conflict of interest
  where single counsel represents multiple codefendants).Â  
Because Petitioner demonstrated an actual conflict of interest, she
  did not have to demonstrate prejudice in order to be entitled to
  post-conviction relief.  Accordingly, we reverse the decision of the PCR judge.
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  On May 6, 2002, a circuit court judge erroneously
  dismissed Petitionerâ€™s application on the mistaken belief that she was no
  longer incarcerated.Â  After Petitionerâ€™s application was reinstated, the
circuit court conducted the hearing on December 14, 2006.
[2]Â Â  The record indicates that plea counsel only asked
the judge to reconsider Husbandâ€™s sentence.
